headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Welcome to The Priceline Group's fourth quarter 2014 conference call.The Priceline Group would like to remind everyone that this call may contain forward-looking statements, which are made pursuant to the Safe Harbor provisions of the Private Securities
componenttext:
Welcome to The Priceline Group's fourth quarter 2014 conference call.
The Priceline Group would like to remind everyone that this call may contain forward-looking statements, which are made pursuant to the Safe Harbor provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future performance and are subject to certain risks, and uncertainties and assumptions that are difficult to predict. Therefore, actual results may differ materially from those expressed, implied or forecast in any such forward-looking statements.  Expressions of future goals or expectations and similar expressions, reflecting something other than historical fact, are intended to identify forward-looking statements.
For a list of factors that could cause the group's actual results to differ materially from those described in the forward-looking statements, please refer to the Safe Harbor statements at the end of the group's earnings press release as well as the group's most recent filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
Unless required by law, The Priceline Group undertakes no obligation to update publicly any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. A copy of the Group's earnings press release, together with an accompanying financial and statistical supplement, is available in the for Investors section of The Priceline Group's website, www.pricelinegroup.com.
And now I'd like to introduce to The Priceline Group's speakers for this afternoon: Darren Houston and Daniel Finnegan. Sir, you may begin.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you very much, and welcome to The Priceline Group's fourth quarter conference call. Thank you for joining us before the markets open this morning in New York. I'm here with Priceline Group CFO, Dan Finnegan.The group reported consolidated gr
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you very much, and welcome to The Priceline Group's fourth quarter conference call. Thank you for joining us before the markets open this morning in New York. I'm here with Priceline Group CFO, Dan Finnegan.
The group reported consolidated gross bookings for the fourth quarter of approximately $10.7 billion, up 17% year-over-year or about 23% on a local currency basis. Non-GAAP earnings per share was $10.85, up 23% versus prior year, surpassing FactSet consensus estimates of $10.10 per share in our guidance for the quarter.
For the full year, The Priceline Group reported gross bookings of just over $50 billion, $346 million room nights, $3.5 billion in adjusted EBITDA, and non-GAAP earnings per share of $53.31, all up about 28% year-over-year.
Gross bookings benefited from growth in hotel  supply at Booking.com, which now has over 600,000 hotels and other accommodations in 212 countries and territories, up 41% over last year. Booking.com continues to invest aggressively in its global supply platform, building substantially differentiated hotel and accommodation supply, content and availability.  Much of that growth in supply is driven by the Vacation Rental, which might than doubled 247,000 properties, including villas, chalets, apartments, aparthotels, and other self-catered products, all of which are instantly confirmable.
It is important to note that because many of our vacationable properties have multiple units, our 247,000 properties actually represent over 1 million instantly bookable and confirmable units within these properties.
We continue to believe in the large untapped potential of the global Vacation Rental opportunities, which is historically been written by a high friction research and fulfillment process. 
In addition to aggressively growing our number of accommodation partners, the group invested nearly $2.6 billion in marketing during the year. While the preponderance of that investment was an online channels, Booking.com continue to build its off-line competencies. Following successful TV launches in the U.S. and Australia in 2013, we also ran effective campaigns in the U.K., Canada and Germany.
We are pleased with the return on total advertising we're seeing in these markets, and we'll continue to explore new markets where the data tells us it makes sense to diversify our ad spend.
2014 was a tale of 2 cities for priceline.com, with solid growth in its retail businesses offset by declines I its OPEC businesses. We believe the pressure in OPEC is reflective of a historically healthy overall travel environment in the United States, which is beneficial to the balance of our group-wide business.
The fast-growing Asia-Pacific market was another critical component to the group's success in 2014. We believe Agoda.com and Booking.com leave the region an intra-asian hotel and accommodation bookings, and we're no harvesting the fruit of our new commercial agreement with CTRIP that we entered last year.
China is a material and faster when portion of our Asia-Pacific business, and we are leaning into that opportunity in a smart and responsible fashion. 
Rentalcars.com accelerated in Q4, comping a quarter last year and which should also accelerated. Rental car's excellent [ph] 2014 from position of strength and have seen this momentum continuing to 2015.
Kayak delivered an outstanding first full year as part of the group, delivering strong top line results of bottom line results significantly exceeded our expectations at the time of acquisition. Kayak has heads down innovating to extend its product leadership and build its brand in Europe. Early signs in Kayak in 2015 are so far quite positive.
OpenTable, our newest member to the group, remains very busy laying the groundwork for its cloud-based re-platforming and international expansion. As I mentioned on the last call, our vision for OpenTable is to expansive, and 2015 will be a profitable investment. It will take time to staff and scale our European sales organization, and there's no shortage of product enhancements, internal plumbing improvement and infrastructure investments to make, so that OpenTable is best positioned to scale to its true global potential.
I will have more to share on OpenTable's progress as the year unfolds, but we are optimistic from everything we are seeing so far and our team is super motivated.
In the U.S., OpenTable continues to achieve high diner growth as it transitions it's restaurant base to its cloud-based offering, and continuous this role in Pay with OpenTable. 
Mobile remains a continued bright spot for all of our brands. Just this past week, Booking.com exceeded 100,000 gross transaction that's before cancellations or amendments on just mobile phones on 2 different dates, and we're still not in high season for booking.
On January 15, we also launched Booking Now on the Apple platform in the United States. Booking Now with our app for spontaneous or last-minute bookers. Our international launch of Booking Now, including the addition of all of our supported languages, will start in earnest next week.
priceline.com leads the group in the percentage of travel book is completed on mobile, on some days now approaching 50%. Kayak and OpenTable both have flourishing businesses on their apps, especially in the United States, which drives strong repeat traffic. 
From a very small part of our business, just a few years ago, mobile has become a mission-critical part of the group, both to deliver transactionsand to deliver great and then experiences for our guests.
Excellent execution in our mobile platform has been critical to the groups success's and overall market share gains this year.
The group performed well in 2014, exceeding expectations throughout the year and growing more in 1 year on an absolute basis than in any year in our history. As we enter 2015, we see continued strong momentum in our business across the board. Our biggest short-term challenge is currency. With over 90% of our business in our international brand, and a significant majority of that being transacted in non-U.S. dollar currencies, mostly, the euro and British pound, but also to a lesser effect, the Brazilian real, Australian Canadian dollars, Russian ruble, Thai baht and Turkish lira, this prevents -- prevents mostly a translation challenge.
Our fundamental growth momentum is measured by units constant currency remained strong, unlike some other companies who have reported, a currency tailwind especially, a transitional challenge and not a mismatch of revenue and expense.
We remain steadfast and committed to our formula of did have innovating the competition. We are in this game for the long run, making a smart and sustainable investments in our products and services everyday of the year. We invest in profitable growth and are earning our customers loyalty through superior customer offerings and branded experiences.
We believe we have a winning, sustainable strategy and have the growing mix of direct business all year, while delivering market-leading organic performance on both the top and bottom line. 
We also believe we can win with strong margins in the face of heated competition, and I have a long history of managing our costs extremely well and plan to continue our track record of strong leverage and margin management.
All that said, we are also not afraid to use our resources to invest assertively when investments make sense, because we believe it currently does in online demand channels and most recently, into our OpenTable and BookingSuite investments, in particular.
We looked at various options to use our capital in the current environment. Today, we're announcing that the Priceline board has given us the authority to repurchase up to $3 billion of our common stock. We believe this is a good use of capital, and reflects our confidence in the long-term prospects of the group.
It has been a privilege this year, past year as group CEO to lead a team of such talented and dedicated people at all the brands. There's no better job on the planet in my opinion. I'm enthusiastic about all of the opportunities facing each of our brands. I want to thank our employees around the world for delivering another terrific year for their brands and for the group.
I will now turn the call over to Dan for the detailed financial review.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Darren. I'll discuss some of the highlights and operating results and cash flows for the quarter and then provide guidance for the first quarter of 2015. Q4 was a strong quarter from both the top and bottom line perspective. Unit growth is an impo
componenttext:
Thanks, Darren. I'll discuss some of the highlights and operating results and cash flows for the quarter and then provide guidance for the first quarter of 2015. Q4 was a strong quarter from both the top and bottom line perspective. Unit growth is an important metric to focus on for our business to understand core performance, excluding the impact of currency.
Room nights both grew by 24% in the fourth quarter, decelerating modestly compared to the 27% growth rate for Q3. Rental car days grew by 16% in Q4, reflecting accelerating retail growth, offset by a decrease for 4 Name Your Own Price rental car reservations. Strong momentum in room nights and rental car day unit growth is carried over into Q1, as we will see in a moment when we review Q1 guidance.
Average daily rates for accommodations or ADRs for Q4 2014, were up on a local currency basis by about 1.5% for the consolidated group. Q4 gross bookings grew by about 23% on a local currency basis and by about 17% in U.S. dollars compared to prior year.
Our Q4 international gross bookings grew by about 27% on a local currency basis and by about 19% in U.S. dollars. Gross bookings for our priceline.com brand business in the U.S. grew by 3%. The Priceline team is doing a great job in improving the experience for our customers on the website, which is driving nice conversion improvements.  The results has been accelerating retail room night and rental car growth. 
However, in Name Your Own Price services, continued to be hamstrung by lack of discounted rates.
Gross profit for the quarter was $1.7 billion and grew by about 33% on a constant currency basis and by 26% in U.S. dollars compared to prior year. Our international operations generated gross profit of $1.4 billion, which grew by about 32% on a constant currency basis, and by 24% in U.S. dollars compared to prior year. Gross profit for our U.S. operations, including OpenTable's U.S. business, amounted to $241 million, which represented 35% growth versus prior year.
OpenTable generated total worldwide revenue in Q4 of about $59 million.
Non-GAAP operating income amounted to 41.4% of gross profit for Q4, which is 132 bps lower than last year. Our operating margins were flat investments we made in off-line advertising and other OpEx to build our brands and support growth initiatives in restaurant reservations and our BookingSuite of hotel marketing services.
Operating margins did come in better than our guidance, however, due mainly to a less than forecasted year-over-year decline in online advertising ROIs.
Adjusted EBITDA for Q4 amounted to $712 million, which exceeded the top end of our guidance range of $665 million, and represents 23% growth versus prior year. Non-GAAP net income grew by 22%, and non-GAAP EPS grew by 23%.
In terms of cash flow, we generated approximately $755 million of cash from operations during the fourth quarter 2014, which is about 36% above last year. We invested $41 million on CapEx and repurchased 443,000 shares of our common stock for $505 million in Q4. 
As Darren mentioned, earlier this month, our board authorized us to repurchase up to $3 billion of our common stock. We expect to execute the program going forward to return capital to shareholders, and if they that we think may cents relative to available cash in the U.S. and potential other uses for such capital.
Our cash and investments amounted to $8 billion at year-end, with about $1.2 billion of that balance in the U.S. We were pleased to recently receive a strong investment-grade credit rating from Moody's, which is in line with our current rating from S&P. This positions us well as we continue to monitor the debt markets in the U.S. and Europe for opportunities to raise capital at attractive rates.
For full year 2014, Priceline Group grew room nights in gross bookings by 28%. Adjusted EBITDA amounted to about $3.5 billion, and grew 29%, while the business generated $2.9 billion of cash from operations. The company delivered an operating margin expressed as non-GAAP operating income divided by gross profit, about 44.7%. 
I thank our people around the world for their hard work and dedication to deliver these strong results. Their talent and relentless execution to add properties, rental car suppliers and restaurants, continuously innovate on our websites and apps and efficiently bringing new customers to our brands with online and off-line advertising, is responsible for our success.
I am also pleased with the balance of outstanding top line and bottom line growth in an ultra-competitive market. Now for Q1 guidance. 
I'd like to take a moment to talk about the impact of foreign currency exchange rates on our financial results. As Darren mentioned, about 90% of our gross bookings and operating income for 2014 are generated by our international brands. Therefore, as we've seen in the past, during the financial crisis and the European sovereign debt crisis, extreme volatility in foreign exchange rates significantly impacts our operating results as we translate them into U.S. dollars.
Our Q1 forecast assumes foreign exchange rates for the remainder of the quarter are equal to yesterday's closing rates. At these exchange rates, our gross bookings, gross profit, operating expenses, adjusted EBITDA and non-GAAP net income, will mathematically translate into significantly fewer dollars than they would've them last year's for exchange rates for Q1 and the remainder of the year.
Specifically, our forecast for 2 over most impactful currencies, the euro and the British pound, assumes rates remain at $1.14 per euro and $1.54 for British pound, which would result in average exchange rates that would be weaker by about 17% for the euro and about 8% for the British pound for Q1 as compared to the prior year.
I highlight that the $1.14 exchange rate assumed in our forecast is about 9% weaker than the $1.25 exchange rate that prevailed at the time we the reported Q3 and most analysts last updated their forecasts.
On the positive side, our expenses are denominated in foreign currencies on the basis similar to our revenues, so our expenses will also translate into fewer dollars. Therefore, our operating margins are not significantly impacted by currency fluctuations and we believe that the impact of currency on our bottom line is generally similar to the top line impact.
However, due to our normal business seasonality, the bottom line currency impact, somewhat less pronounced in Q1 and slightly more pronounced in Q3. Although the stronger dollar has a significant negative impact on our growth expressed in dollars, the fundamental performance of our business is still evident in the resilient unit growth driving our forecasted total gross bookings, international gross bookings and gross profit growth on a constant currency basis.
We believe the true performances of our business will eventually show through in our U.S. dollar financial statements when the dollar stabilizes relative to other currencies in general, and the euro, in particular. We are pleased with the high growth rates the business has consistently delivered over the past several years despite its size. The travel market remains fundamentally healthy from an occupancy and ADR perspective broadly, and in Europe. Our guidance reflects a strong start to the first quarter, and our assumption that are growth rates will decelerate as we proceed through the remainder of the quarter due to the size of our business.
For Q1 guidance, we are forecasting total gross bookings to grow by 14% to 21% on a constant currency basis and by 2% to 9% in U.S. dollars, with the U.S. gross bookings growing by about 0 to 5%. We expect international gross bookings to grow by 17% to 24% on a constant currency basis, and by 3% to 10% in U.S. dollars. Our Q1 forecast assumes that local currency ADRs for the consolidated group will be up by slightly less than 1% compared to the prior-year period.
We expect the Q1 revenue to grow year-over-year by approximately 4% to 11%, and gross profits grow by 21% to 28% on a local currency basis, and by 9% to 16% in U.S. dollars. We expect that declines in our Name Your Own Price service will continue to negatively impact revenue growth rates in Q1.
We expect about 550 bps of de-leverage in non-GAAP operating margins compared to prior year, expressed as operating income as a percentage of gross profit, driven mainly by nonadvertising operating expenses. 
As we have done in the past, we are investing in OpEx to add people, offices and IT capacity to build up the capability of the business to handle future growth. Q1 also reflects OpEx for OpenTable and our BookingSuite of hotel marketing services. Our Q1 online advertising forecast reflects our actual results to date, and assumes increased pressure on ad efficiency throughout the remainder of the quarter based upon the trends we have experienced over the last couple of years. 
Investments and OpEx and advertising, typically have a more pronounced impact on profitability in Q1, where we are in a lower percentage of our annual gross profit due to the normal seasonality for our business.  While we are not giving earnings guidance beyond Q1, we do expect the pressure on operating margins from nonadvertising OpEx to significantly diminish as we proceed throughout the year and lap the OpenTable acquisition and the launch of our BookingSuite initiative.
Adjusted EBITDA is expected to range between $475 million and $510 million, which at the midpoint, is a decrease of 4% versus prior year. Our non-GAAP EPS forecast includes an estimated cash income tax rate of approximately 15%, comprised of international income taxes and Alternative Minimum Tax and state income taxes in the U.S. We are targeting non-GAAP fully diluted EPS of approximately $7.20 to $7.75 per share, which at the midpoint is a decrease of 4% versus prior year.
Our non-GAAP EPS guidance assumes a fully diluted share count of 52.7 million shares based upon yesterday's closing stock price. We've forecast GAAP EPS between $5.25 and $5.80 per share for Q1. The difference between our GAAP and non-GAAP results is driven by non-GAAP adjustments that are detailed in our earnings release.
Consistent with past practice, which contracts in place to successfully shield our first quarter EBITDA and net earnings from many further fluctuation in the euro and British pound versus the dollar between now and the end of the quarter. But these hedges do not offset the impact of translation on our gross bookings, revenue, gross profit or operating income, do not hedge as against much of fluctuations and other recurrencies, and do not hedge our earnings beyond the first quarter.
Although we remain concerned about economic conditions in general, and in our key European markets, in particular, our forecast does not assume any further deterioration in macroeconomic conditions. We will now take your questions.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Heath Terry of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Heath Terry of Goldman Sachs.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions. This could provide us a little more detail on you mentioned the ADR growth there being less than 1% in the quarter. But if you look more specifically, particularly, the Eurozone, what you're seeing from a consumer demand perspe
componenttext: Just a couple of questions. This could provide us a little more detail on you mentioned the ADR growth there being less than 1% in the quarter. But if you look more specifically, particularly, the Eurozone, what you're seeing from a consumer demand perspective and just willingness to spend on travel, but whether the day-to-day data points that you're seeing are positive or negative, from any sort of perspective? And then you've mentioned that as we go through our past Q1, that the operating margin pressure should diminish, as that happens, are there -- are you -- are there incremental positive ROI growth channels from a customer acquisition or business acquisition perspective that you see out there, that you can allocate those dollars to accelerate growth, or do you simply expect to see that fall to the bottom line?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Heath. I'll take -- this is Darren. I'll take the ADR growth European economy issue, and maybe Dan can comment on the -- on operating margins. No, in general, certainly, the -- everyone knows what's going on with the euro, but we're not sett
componenttext: Okay. Thanks, Heath. I'll take -- this is Darren. I'll take the ADR growth European economy issue, and maybe Dan can comment on the -- on operating margins. No, in general, certainly, the -- everyone knows what's going on with the euro, but we're not setting overall that there are big issues with consumer demand in Europe. Now it's kind of a mixed bag. Certainly, our Russian outbound is down for obvious reasons, or the Russian domestic travel is still quite strong. France, specifically, is still in a bit them on a malaise, both as a destination and as bookers. But that's made up for the fact that the Brits as bookers, are very strong, the German, as bookers are strong. And Southern Europe, it looks like it's going to be very popular in the spring and summer. So overall, Europe is not -- the U.S. is definitely one of the hottest markets in the world, but Europe is holding up quite well, at least the early signs in 2015.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Heath, on operating margins. So yes, we said that we expect the pressure to diminish as we go throughout the year as it relates to other nonadvertising OpEx expenses. We already advertise aggressively in all the variable channels, and we'll spend on l
componenttext: And Heath, on operating margins. So yes, we said that we expect the pressure to diminish as we go throughout the year as it relates to other nonadvertising OpEx expenses. We already advertise aggressively in all the variable channels, and we'll spend on limited amount of money there, regardless of what's going on with OpEx, as long as we can get our fair return on our investment. So the impact is less margin pressure from OpEx should benefit bottom line. And the -- how advertising plays out is just a completely separate story.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Justin Post of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Justin Post of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just talk a little bit them high level in the space, obviously, Expedia has had a lot of acquisition news lately. Does that really change anything for Priceline, and they do have their room nights up on but at a faster rate period, so how does that affect
componenttext: Just talk a little bit them high level in the space, obviously, Expedia has had a lot of acquisition news lately. Does that really change anything for Priceline, and they do have their room nights up on but at a faster rate period, so how does that affect the overall environment, can you provide any help on that? And then secondly, on mobile. It looks like mobile is growing as a piece of your business. Are the upfront costs of acquired card customers more there, and do you expect a longer payback, are they coming back more frequently direct on mobile, maybe a little bit about the mobile channel versus PC.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, Justin. Thanks. This is Darren. I'll guess, I'll take both questions. First of all, as it relates to what as Travelocity, the pending deal with Orbitz, it's Expedia I can't exactly -- I don't know exactly what they're doing, but it sounds like a con
componenttext: Okay, Justin. Thanks. This is Darren. I'll guess, I'll take both questions. First of all, as it relates to what as Travelocity, the pending deal with Orbitz, it's Expedia I can't exactly -- I don't know exactly what they're doing, but it sounds like a consolidation strategy. Our focus as a group is quite different than that. We're very focused primarily on organic growth and execution. And from an activation standpoint, we're focused buying in premium, winning brands that either add new geographies or business verticals, or competencies, new channels that we can add to our existing brands. So if you look at our history as a group, whether it was buying Booking.com to compete in Europe, in Asia, rental cars and rental cars, Kayak and Meadow, OpenTable and restaurants, and then recently Buuteeq, to help build our BookingSuite business. It's all been adjacent growth versus doubling or tripling down on similar brands. I don't view -- I don't see the deal that Expedia has made. If it passes, it's being a negative for our group. I think if anything that consolidates, clarifies competition, and there's still plenty of room to grow. If you think travel market was a $1 trillion market, recently someone said it was a $1.3 trillion market, so if you add but all of our business and Expedia's business together, it's still less than 10% of the total opportunity space. And if you look at the U.S. specifically, for us, it's all upside, and we plan to work very hard to continue to increase our share in the U.S. market. So to me, it just shows that there's just tremendous potential ahead, and we're just staying very focused on what we do well, and I'm sure Expedia will do the same. So I don't see that overall, it's a negative. In terms of Expedia's growth rates, we have obviously always prided ourselves in being very highly profitable and continuing to grow very fast. I'm super proud of the 28% growth on top and bottom line that we've printed in 2014. It's always good to remind you that -- when we talk about our room nights, they're all 100% organic, and that's just a very different result, the way you're seeing at Expedia. But I do get them a lot of credit, they seem to have a great quarter, but we just have a different philosophy as it relates to building business for the long term. And then, mobile, specifically. Yes, mobile is -- I've been here now 3.5 years and it's by far, is the biggest thing that's changed in our business, and it's causing all sorts of issues and questions in terms of how do you generate demand, how do you build experiences. But as I've always said, for an e-commerce player like us, mobile is a net-net positive. It's allowing us to serve customers over multiple screens, and whether they arrive first on a phone or a tablet or a PC, it's not important to us, it's how do we basically become relevant to them, other than just being a transaction. How does OpenTable or Booking or Agoda create more relevant CME and then experience that they're having on a local basis? True enough, we do spend money on buying business that originates on mobile phones, and that market is still -- it's still not the most perfect market, it's still quite chaotic. But we've felt we've gotten a lot smarter about how we buy our business. Some brands are very app driven, if you look at OpenTable or Kayak, other brands are very mobile web driven, and then brands like Booking have a little bit of both. And we feel if anything, our -- the skills that we've built on the desktop, we're feeling as good, if not better, about the skills that we're applying in the mobile environment to buying new demand. And I don't think the increase in mobile to any degree -- because we have a common ROI standard, i don't think the increase in mobile to any degree has driven us to any lower standards. If anything, the one real positive, it's driving more of our business direct to our brands versus having to buy it.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Doug Anmuth of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Doug Anmuth of JPMorgan.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you just talk a little more about the investments in 1Q in OpenTable and BookingSuite can just talk about the key initiatives there? And then also you mentioned that you're starting to harvest the food from the CTRIP relationship. Could you provide so
componenttext: Can you just talk a little more about the investments in 1Q in OpenTable and BookingSuite can just talk about the key initiatives there? And then also you mentioned that you're starting to harvest the food from the CTRIP relationship. Could you provide some more color on some of the benefits that you're seeing there as well?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay, Doug, I'll take -- this is Darren again, and I'll take those. So first of all, let me talk, first of all, OpenTable. Since we bought it, we've made a massive investment in reply forming the OpenTable B2B software, it's now going to be all clou
componenttext: Okay. Okay, Doug, I'll take -- this is Darren again, and I'll take those. So first of all, let me talk, first of all, OpenTable. Since we bought it, we've made a massive investment in reply forming the OpenTable B2B software, it's now going to be all cloud-based. The whole front end has been re-platformed so we can run AD experimentation on it. There's been a lot of best practice sharing. You're going to see the OpenTable product now improve at a very dramatic pace, because we put it onto the new modern cloud-based platform. We've also now posted our position that are beginning hiring for a number of international cities. I'd let you do your own research there, in terms of which cities we're expanding into. So I would say it's time today has been a lot of best practice sharing, getting some of the plumbing done in 2015, for us is a big expense investment here for OpenTable. And as we've always said, we're doing here to create something that is going to be truly a global platform and a modern e-commerce platform, and we're -- we remain very bullish on the opportunity with that asset. And certainly, today, has been performing abovev the level that we had expected it to. But really, the best is yet to come. And when it relates to BookingSuite, we bought Buuteeq and a smaller company called Hotel Ninjas. That team now has been completely brought into Booking.com, we've rebranded at BookingSuite. We're now in the market with a number of products, mostly website products. The demand of those products is very strong. And we're just now in the rhythm of really trying to scale the old Buuteeq business now that's fully integrated with Booking. And the receptivity from the market has been very strong. So what we're doing there is building out our SaaS-based business, but it takes a little bit of time to get going, but it's a really nice annuity revenue stream. But almost as importantly, it's bringing us closer to our hotel partners and showing that as a company, we can add value to them as well as a marketing services Software provider. And then finally, with CTRIP, there, I'd say that the biggest highlight has been significantly growing outbound business, both for Agoda and Booking.com on CTRIP. That reflects, of course, a very strong Chinese market. We've also seen our non-CTRIP business, by the way, growing very strong. So CTRIP now is a branded experience, so customers are learning about Booking.com and Agoda, and that's obviously very valuable to us. The other side of the CTRIP deal was getting see CTRIP hotels onto the Booking.com website. We now have from that's called hotels on our website. It's taken a little bit longer because we've had to work to make those hotels -- and to upgrade the products so that it was at the level of the products that we have in our website otherwise, but we're getting good traction there and we look in the coming quarters to significantly, accelerate our rollout of CTRIP properties in China. I'd mention this before but what of our biggest challenges in China, is most business in Chinese hotels is domestic. And we're really are very strong on inbound and outbound, and the CTRIP product portfolio is going to allow us to offset a very competitive selection of properties for domestic Chinese guests as well. So those are the 3 -- CTRIP in particular, you've all followed it, they've -- they're in a super competitive environment. We're really supportive of James and his team, we think they have the strongest hand in the market, and we still believe that today and we're proud of the deal we have. And we're working really closely with them as they try it competitive battles that they're fighting, which is largely been a domestic Chinese challenge.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ross Sandler of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ross Sandler of Deutsche Bank.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just had 2 questions. So first one, Airbnb called out that they had 550,000 travelers that used them for New Year's Eve this past year in like 20,000 cities or something. So this isn't exactly apples-to-apples to your 800,000, 900,000 room nights per ni
componenttext: I just had 2 questions. So first one, Airbnb called out that they had 550,000 travelers that used them for New Year's Eve this past year in like 20,000 cities or something. So this isn't exactly apples-to-apples to your 800,000, 900,000 room nights per night average in the fourth quarter. But I guess, just big picture, how do you view Airbnb competitively in the hotel space longer term? And then a quick follow-up to the earlier question on mobile unit economics. I guess, I'll ask this a different way, but as you guys move away from paid searches and marketing channel, do you see the online marketing as a percent of gross profit, staying in this kind of 31% range or could that get better one day? That's all.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. This is Darren. I'll take the first one, a first shot and the second to Dan, anything to add. Yes, with respect to Airbnb, we have a lot of respect to what they're doing. It's -- it is still as good as their website, it's still a relatively high fri
componenttext: Okay. This is Darren. I'll take the first one, a first shot and the second to Dan, anything to add. Yes, with respect to Airbnb, we have a lot of respect to what they're doing. It's -- it is still as good as their website, it's still a relatively high friction process of booking at Airbnb. But the whole sharing economy, peer-to-peer is a real force. I'll remind people that on average, everyday, we have more than 1 million guess, if you do the math. And if you look at the total number of units that are actually bookable on Booking.com, it far exceeds what's available on Airbnb. The interesting dynamic is really happening in the vacation rentals space. We're coming into the end of the market with an instantly bookable, immediately confirmable product. They're coming from the bottom-up with the sharing economy. And there is a lot of interest among our consumers in self catered products. And whether that's product ultimately ends up being somebody's sofa or being in a aparthotel room in Paris, nobody knows. But one of the things that Airbnb is really helping us with is the rules in this space, are traditionally been very foggy and gray. And city by city around the world, the rules are now getting written and that helps us a, lot because we're always going to play on the white side of the rules. But there've always been a little bit foggy, and we'll see where that all goes at the end of the day. There seems some -- we don't see a big impact on hotel demand based on this new Adventa, what I would call self-catered demand, and that's all up Airbnb, us, other players. But maybe, one day, you'll see that shift. And obviously, the big hotel brands, I don't think they're sitting still either. We see a lot of properties, for instance, in Europe, they have a hotel and they have an apartment block, and behind the hotel, you use a hotel front desk. But then as a family, you might stay in the apartment, and that's -- that kind of new behavior is a reaction, I think, to some of this current trend, at least. And then as it relates to mobile unit economics, I should also qualify that mobile web search is primarily still, a Google business. And it is working better and better. So when we -- even when we acquire a customer on the phone, one of the best ways to do it is through Google and through their web search. But as I look forward, what we've generally done this is become more direct, we're leaning even heavier into some of these channels. We've certainly keep ROI standards, but I can't particularly say, if long, long term online will be a lesser percentage -- but we will continue to adjust our marketing mix and we think that our margin level that, we need to keep throwing out the fishing net to find more and more customers, and we're not satisfied just to work out the loyalty of our existing customer base. So a lot of it depends on the opportunity to cast the fishing net in an ROI positive fashion. And it's hard to really predict that based on the competitive dynamics of some of these markets. But certainly, what you're seeing -- the one thing that is really, is we're having adjust our marketing mix over time based on mobile specifically, but also based on the ability of the -- let's call it the non-Google participants to create products that are ROI positive for us. And we are seeing targets in places like Facebook, for instance, and others where they're improving the ability for directors response performance marketers, like The Priceline Group to buy their product demand, that's a real good thing for us, because it hadn't been that case traditionally over the past.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I agree. We're not moving away from paid search, we're moving closer to -- we're looking for every opportunity to spend money with our partners to drive business profitably. We're seeing nice growth in our direct business, which we hope will continue over
componenttext: I agree. We're not moving away from paid search, we're moving closer to -- we're looking for every opportunity to spend money with our partners to drive business profitably. We're seeing nice growth in our direct business, which we hope will continue over time. But -- and that may cause what you would perceive to be moving away, but we're actually driving with both speed, partnering with our paid search partners to drive more opportunities for both of us.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mark Mahaney of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mark Mahaney of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two questions, please. I think 2 quarters ago, I think you quantified Vacation Rentals as a percentage of your total bookings. Could you give us an update there, is it exceeded 10%, perhaps, on a trailing 12-month basis? And then secondly, Darren, you tal
componenttext: Two questions, please. I think 2 quarters ago, I think you quantified Vacation Rentals as a percentage of your total bookings. Could you give us an update there, is it exceeded 10%, perhaps, on a trailing 12-month basis? And then secondly, Darren, you talked about having used acquisitions to expand into newer areas, and you've mentioned a couple of them. I want to ask your thoughts about expanding into things like local attractions on -- and air, especially internationally? How do you think about those as incremental or adjacent market opportunities, how high on the priority list, or low on the priority list, are those 2 things, particularly, attractions and international air?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Mark. So we don't have any new numbers on Vacation Rentals, we gave a trailing 12 months, but I will say, is the Vacation Rental business is growing our business. And so the next time we say a number, maybe we'll do it a year -- from the fir
componenttext: Okay. Thanks, Mark. So we don't have any new numbers on Vacation Rentals, we gave a trailing 12 months, but I will say, is the Vacation Rental business is growing our business. And so the next time we say a number, maybe we'll do it a year -- from the first time we said the number, you can think about it in that way. So it's becoming a greater proportion of our business. I always -- I also fly so you've got to be careful of property count, that's why we added the Vacation Rental sub-number, because it -- those properties do come in with less units than our traditional hotels. And that's why you will see our property count continued to expand the rate faster than our overall business because we're bringing on less units per property. And I think that'll continue to be the case going forward. I'd say that and I don't -- and we're not, by any means, done with acquisitions. There's a lot more to do -- and the next move on Vacation Rentals is to really address the homeowner versus property managed vacation rental product, and we're underway to doing that. And in terms of acquisitions or opportunities space, number 1, I would say, we have lot to digest right now. And we're in, what I consider to be the most attractive spaces. And the addition of restaurants is just an amazing opportunity for the group. Air is a very low-margin business, and it's right with customer service concerns. And our play in air right now is a little piece at Priceline, but also of course, Kayak, which plays off of both OTAs and direct air. And even though air is not a very attractive business from an EBITDA perspective, it is an important part of travel and we want to make sure that whatever we do in air that we remain relevant in air. And certainly, with over 90 partnerships with airlines all around the world, including Ryanair and easyJet and KLM, et cetera, we play an important partnership of how do you monetize air into things like hotel bookings. But as I look forward, yes, attractions are interesting. We're doing a lot of experimentation right now with various elements across. Always we're looking at things that yes, we can make money off, but much more importantly, what are the things that we can cross-sell that improves the spirits with the consumer and enhances their loyalty. So if you follow Booking right now, for instance, you'll see us do a lot of preaching of emails, and you'll see us now, we have insider guides to the top cities in the world. And within those guides, you'll see us testing and experimenting with various things. But again, we're not going to become the tchotchke shop itself 50 different things, to just make a little bit more money. We're really cognizant of what does the user really want us to do. And if any of those things gets big traction, then we'll figure out, how do we -- should we enter the space organically through acquisition or some -- or an alliance or some other mode, is a way to think about it. But at this specific moment, yes, we have -- we got our hands full and we are by and large, focused on organic execution.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mike Olson of Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mike Olson of Piper Jaffray.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: So you mentioned Vacation Rentals again as a focus. And I think you just said he'll be looking at addressing the homeowner property category. Does that present more challenges than what you've done so far in the space with property manager inventory? So I
componenttext: So you mentioned Vacation Rentals again as a focus. And I think you just said he'll be looking at addressing the homeowner property category. Does that present more challenges than what you've done so far in the space with property manager inventory? So I guess, should the pace of VR inventory addition comes slow in the coming quarters because of that? And then secondly, and totally separately, does the $3 billion buyback have any sort of specific time frame on it, like is it an authorization for 1 or 2 years, or is it just an open-ended authorization?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, Mike. No, I -- every -- since we started, primarily focusing on hotels, even moving into bed and breakfast and the hostels and even treehouses and igloos and everything we've added to the site, has presented new challenges. And what we do is
componenttext: Yes, thanks, Mike. No, I -- every -- since we started, primarily focusing on hotels, even moving into bed and breakfast and the hostels and even treehouses and igloos and everything we've added to the site, has presented new challenges. And what we do is we bring it then, we experiment with it. We adjust our businesses them. Recently, we've rolled out the simple extra map, and we've got a lot of other things in the pipeline to specifically address the needs, all the way down to the single unit, single property, single owner model. I mean, that's ultimately, as a company, it's our destination. We're here to be the world's largest inventory and selection of accommodations, at the best price, at the simplest experience. And this very much did that. I don't -- I honestly, don't believe the challenges are insurmountable. But it takes a lot of work in an industry this traditionally operated in a very different fashion, than modern e-commerce, which is the ability to buy things at a price and you'll actually book them without ever having to talk to the seller of the product. And that's what we are working towards. And frankly, I'm quite optimistic, not that we have the answer to everything at this moment, but we've got really smart teams working on this right now. And I'll -- over to Dan on the $3 billion.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the stock buybacks authorization, Mike, similar to all the authorizations we've had in the past, that's open-ended. There's no specific time frame by which we need to execute that. If you look at our track record, we've been active in the market. In Q4
componenttext: On the stock buybacks authorization, Mike, similar to all the authorizations we've had in the past, that's open-ended. There's no specific time frame by which we need to execute that. If you look at our track record, we've been active in the market. In Q4, we bought back over $500 million, over the last couple of years, we've bought back $1.6 billion worth of our stock. That said, this is the biggest buyback authorization we've ever gotten from our board. We got to be where we want to use it, we'll be active in the market but we're not going to constrain ourselves by stating the pace at which we'll execute it.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Naved Khan with Cantor Fitzgerald.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Naved Khan with Cantor Fitzgerald.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a question. When on the TV ad spending last year, it grew faster than your online spend at the top, as the way the growth and gross profits. And I know you're not guiding 2015, but can you just sort of talk about what to expect for the year in terms
componenttext: Just a question. When on the TV ad spending last year, it grew faster than your online spend at the top, as the way the growth and gross profits. And I know you're not guiding 2015, but can you just sort of talk about what to expect for the year in terms of TV ad spend? And then on a different topic, have you tested the cross-seller traffic, cross-sell synergies between the core travel and OpenTable, and what have you seen so far?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm going to let Dan take the first one. I'll take the second one.
componenttext: Yes, I'm going to let Dan take the first one. I'll take the second one.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: HI, Naved. On the TV ad spend, we're not giving any guidance for the year. We didn't mention it as it relates to Q1, being a back or positively or negatively related to guidance, so you can assume it's fairly neutral. As we've added more and more markets
componenttext: HI, Naved. On the TV ad spend, we're not giving any guidance for the year. We didn't mention it as it relates to Q1, being a back or positively or negatively related to guidance, so you can assume it's fairly neutral. As we've added more and more markets over the last couple of years, and then you continue to spend in those markets at the same amount or some relative increase that's not growing as fast as our business, the pressure on operating margins subsides to an extent. That said, we still like the results we've seen in all the markets where we launched our advertising, and we're likely to launch an additional markets this year, particularly for Booking.com. And so when we do that, you can see from quarter-to-quarter some operating pressure when we had those new markets.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: And maybe, Naved, on the second question, the way I like to think about cross-sell is a very narrow way to think about it, that would be -- I made a hotel booking and immediately, I'm going to make a restaurant booking. And I think of the much bigger oppo
componenttext: And maybe, Naved, on the second question, the way I like to think about cross-sell is a very narrow way to think about it, that would be -- I made a hotel booking and immediately, I'm going to make a restaurant booking. And I think of the much bigger opportunity is cross promotion. Meaning, a, "I live in Italy and I love using Booking.com, and oh, you can also do that with restaurants." And that's the part that we've seen the biggest interest. When we look at our insider guidance and our reach up e-mails, the biggest thing people are interested in who book accommodations is restaurants. The restaurants nearby, where they booked. And the ability on that first night, if they're arriving late, where can I eat? Many of our hotels have restaurants, and has a competitive thing within the space, with the person who's sitting in there and now we're absolutely confident that there's significant interest on that. But we need to then get, of course, if great relevant content, get the OpenTable reviews, the photos, et cetera, and really lay those 2 things together. But we're quite optimistic. I'd say all of that in OpenTable proposition, it's not going to grow as a primary just because of Booking.com. OpenTable will need to stand on its own as a business, which it has in the United States, and I'm confident will internationally. Booking.com will be a nice new group of tens of millions of customers that we can introduce the concept to. And that's what -- that's really, the way I think about it versus get a hotel booking, get a restaurant booking. Although, by the way, we've tested that, it works, but it's not like the biggest idea in terms of the synergy between the brands.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Tom White of Macquarie.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Tom White of Macquarie.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think in your prepared remarks, you talked about Booking and Agoda you guides believe now the leaders in Intra-Asia travel. Could you maybe just talk a bit about what metrics that space done, and why do you believe the playbook there is working? And the
componenttext: I think in your prepared remarks, you talked about Booking and Agoda you guides believe now the leaders in Intra-Asia travel. Could you maybe just talk a bit about what metrics that space done, and why do you believe the playbook there is working? And then just quickly, you talked about less pressure on ad ROIs in the quarter than expected, maybe talk a bit about what's driving that? I'm curious if any of it relates to your emerging markets? Are you seeing any of the recent investments you made there starting to pay out in terms of repeat visits?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, yes. Thanks, Tom. Yes, it's really -- we say intra-Asia travel because it's really is, has been the strength of the group. If you look the Agoda brand in Southeast Asia, it really is the leading way that people book accommodations in Southeast Asia.
componenttext: Okay, yes. Thanks, Tom. Yes, it's really -- we say intra-Asia travel because it's really is, has been the strength of the group. If you look the Agoda brand in Southeast Asia, it really is the leading way that people book accommodations in Southeast Asia. And then with the addition of Booking.com, which brings travelers from all over the world, into Asia and then Asians among Asia, they really play to our strong of brand. There are a large, very large domestic OTAs in the market, the CTRIPs, the, the Rakutens, who do actually be high-volume business. But their business is largely domestic, and we are pretty good sense from our hotel partners, that we're the leading players from a market share standpoint, in terms of how Asians move within Asia, meaning, from country to country. And. . .

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: And for the second part, Tom, regarding Q4, we said the favorability for operating margins was mainly driven by better than forecasted online ad ROIs, so not so much of a mix issue direct growing faster,  that's also in there, but that was in our forecast
componenttext: And for the second part, Tom, regarding Q4, we said the favorability for operating margins was mainly driven by better than forecasted online ad ROIs, so not so much of a mix issue direct growing faster,  that's also in there, but that was in our forecast. We don't get the specific so what's driving those better ROIs. But you know all the elements that go into it, you've got CPCs, conversion which we've got our great teams at all of our brands working hard at everyday to improve, cancellation rates, even economics. So the way that all blended out in Q4 was favorable to what we had assumed in our forecast.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Brian Fitzgerald of Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Brian Fitzgerald of Jefferies.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: A quick question on your thoughts around loyalty programs and their impacts on consumer travel behaviors. Is that something that's important to you guides, are you going to be investing around that? Do you like your bit of a disadvantage relative to some
componenttext: A quick question on your thoughts around loyalty programs and their impacts on consumer travel behaviors. Is that something that's important to you guides, are you going to be investing around that? Do you like your bit of a disadvantage relative to some of the other OTAs that have been investing around loyalty programs?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, Brian. Well, we have -- Agoda has a loyalty program that was a very points driven. Our -- I guess, it's a much my philosophy as some of the brands CEOs and I'm -- I grew up at Starbucks and other places. My own view on what we've seen in the
componenttext: Yes, thanks, Brian. Well, we have -- Agoda has a loyalty program that was a very points driven. Our -- I guess, it's a much my philosophy as some of the brands CEOs and I'm -- I grew up at Starbucks and other places. My own view on what we've seen in the data, is the customers are most loyal when you give them a great experience. And that's what we really be focused on. And it's driven -- if you look at repeat behavior, if you look at a number of bookings and a share of wallet in a year, we've seen in our biggest brands. They don't have a formal 4 and quote loyalty program, significant increases in those kind of metrics every single year that we've been in business. So that's what we focus on. Now the other question, though, is for high-volume travel, what do you do? And most of our business is built off of leisure travelers who don't actually book that often. But for high-volume travel, it seems like loyalty is an aspect. By the way, it's a very deep aspect more in the United States than it is in many other parts of the world, where people take a lot more leisure travel versus pure business travel. So we've always been interested in, what is the role of points and loyalty programs, what role should the group play in that. By the way, some of these programs, you think they drive them to be more layout, but they can actually make some more dissatisfied with you, because people will give you points and then make it harder and harder for you to use your points, that's what marketers do. And CFOs do it, Tony, as well, looking at Dan. so there's always a caution with these things. But we're obviously very interested in it. It hasn't been a big issue for us in the past. So when you do like a specific pockets of high-volume traveler, that's where probably we have the greatest going forward interest in this topic.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our final question comes from Ron Josey of JMP Securities.
componenttext: And our final question comes from Ron Josey of JMP Securities.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll be brief. I was just following up on an earlier question, I believe, that Darren, you had sort of answered, specifically on segmentation, and one I think, perhaps in finding non-Google participants, want to get your thoughts on margin of millennials?
componenttext: I'll be brief. I was just following up on an earlier question, I believe, that Darren, you had sort of answered, specifically on segmentation, and one I think, perhaps in finding non-Google participants, want to get your thoughts on margin of millennials? I think you said in the past, millennials have a penchant for non-hotel activity. You launched Booking.now recently, the new TV ad campaign, I think, maybe focused on them as well. So as you think about, sort of a new segments not resting on your existing customers, I'm curious on those, on your approach there?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, Ron. That's a great question. Yes, we're very cognizant of millennials. I think another thing I would add to your list, if any chase, is things like Booking Now, they basically like -- not to go to Paris to London or New York, they just to wa
componenttext: Yes, thanks, Ron. That's a great question. Yes, we're very cognizant of millennials. I think another thing I would add to your list, if any chase, is things like Booking Now, they basically like -- not to go to Paris to London or New York, they just to wander off into the countryside. Many of them don't have computers, they only have phones. So it's -- thinking all of all those things and as well as other products on the site. We're one of the risk leaders in hostels. If you go to any hostel in Europe, a lot of people are using Booking.com to book hospitals. So making sure that we're relevant to this next generation of travelers, is also helping us make sure we're relevant with the emerging lifestyle of the consumers. And so we do a lot of work not -- I wouldn't say, traditional marketing work, like we're not buying ads on just programs that millennials watch, that's never been something we do. But we target them more from a data perspective, and also making sure that the product that we have is relevant for their lifestyles. And the least the data that we see shows that we have a very large group of young people who use Booking.com on a regular basis, even backpacking through Europe, we're a relevant thing. We're not just a rich person's product, that obviously keeps the brand healthy. And we hope that the hostels payers become hotel bookers, et cetera, through their lifecycle. But it's a good question and certainly, watching my own children -- the world is changing very, very fast, and we want to make sure we relevant the way that they use their screens versus the way that, Dan and I would use our screens, which is quite different.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. And at this time, I'd like to turn the call back to management for closing remarks.
componenttext: Thank you. And at this time, I'd like to turn the call back to management for closing remarks.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, thank you very much and thank you, all, for joining the call. And we look forward to getting back into in the execution here. And I think Dan mentioned that currency is a translation challenge for us, but as a team, we're continue to be very f
componenttext: Okay. Well, thank you very much and thank you, all, for joining the call. And we look forward to getting back into in the execution here. And I think Dan mentioned that currency is a translation challenge for us, but as a team, we're continue to be very focused on organically executing through the way that we've always done. And we're very optimistic in where the business will be going in the coming orders, years, et cetera. So thank you.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
