headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Welcome to The Priceline Group's a first quarter 2015 conference call. The Priceline Group would like to remind everyone that this call may contain forward-looking statements, which are made pursuant to the Safe Harbor provisions of the Private Securiti
componenttext:
Welcome to The Priceline Group's a first quarter 2015 conference call. 
The Priceline Group would like to remind everyone that this call may contain forward-looking statements, which are made pursuant to the Safe Harbor provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future performance and are subject to certain risks and uncertainties and assumptions that are difficult to predict. Therefore, actual results may differ materially from those expressed, implied or forecasted in any such forward-looking statements. Expressions of future goals or expectations and similar expressions reflecting something other than historical fact are intended to identify forward-looking statements.
For list of factors that could cause the group's actual results to differ materially from those described in the forward-looking statements, please refer to the Safe Harbor statement at the end of the group's earnings press release as well as the groups most recent filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Unless required by law, The Priceline Group undertakes no obligation to update publicly any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. A copy of the group's earnings press release, together with an accompanying financial and statistical supplement, is available in the for Investors section of the process groups website, www.pricelinegroup.com.
And now I'd like to introduce The Priceline Group speakers for this afternoon: Darren Huston and Daniel Finnegan. Go ahead, gentlemen.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you very much, and welcome to The Priceline Group's first quarter conference call. Thank you for joining us for the markets opened this morning in New York. I'm here in Amsterdam, with Priceline Group CFO, Dan Finnegan.The group reported c
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you very much, and welcome to The Priceline Group's first quarter conference call. Thank you for joining us for the markets opened this morning in New York. 
I'm here in Amsterdam, with Priceline Group CFO, Dan Finnegan.
The group reported consolidated gross bookings for the fourth quarter of approximately $13.8 billion, up 12% year-over-year, or about 26% on a local-currency basis. 
Room nights exceeded $100 million for the first time during our quarter, while growth accelerated slightly to 25%. 
Non-GAAP earnings per share was $8.12, up 4% versus prior year, surpassing FactSet consensus estimates of $7.72 per share in our guidance for the quarter. 
Our U.S. dollar denominated growth rates were substantially impacted by the stronger dollar.
Our International business recorded 29% gross bookings growth on a local-currency basis, up from 27% last quarter. Gross bookings benefited from growth in hotel supply at Booking.com, which now has over 640,000 hotels and other accommodations in over 200 countries and territories, up 40% over last year. 
We are continuing to ramp new property acquisition, including individually-owned vacation rentals, with new onboarding tools that allow owners to list their property quickly and easily on our website. Vacation rentals nearly doubled year-over-year to 275,000, instantly bookable and confirmable properties,
including villas, chalets, apartments, aparthotels and other self-catered products. 
Two important omissions were also launched to Booking.com in the fourth quarter: Booking Now, our mobile phone app for spontaneous brokers; and BookingSuite, our partner-facing Support Services platform.  Both launches were instituted well in early results are encouraging. Each of these growth extensions represent Innovation Beachhead that will be further expanded upon in the coming weeks, months, quarters. 
International results also benefited from agoda.com and rentalcars.com, both of which accelerated in the quarter. 
KAYAK and OpenTable continue to pursue the international opportunity, and while much merger has been done and both businesses are growing, there still a lot of potential ahead of us.
KAYAK is focused on product innovation and brand building, and has been some solid business progress, particularly in Europe. 
OpenTable has now more or less completed its technical re-platforming, to a more modern cloud-based architecture. We are now executing plans to optimize the product and rolling out globally.
Against these plans, we will take a determined but test-and-learn approach over the coming quarters as we have a with all our businesses. Demand for OpenTable solutions from both restaurants and customers, remains very strong. 
Priceline.com's domestic growth continued to be hampered by the shrinking of opaque Opie business. Priceline.com's Retail business remains healthy, including acceleration in the retail hotels and a new management team there, is poised to rejuvenate and maximize the potential of the priceline.com brand.
We also acquired rocket miles in the first quarter, and innovative hotel booking platform for frequent flyers based in Chicago. Rocket Miles is being managed independently, as part of our Priceline ventures portfolio. 
Mobile's uninterrupted growth in share of our business continues. From Booking.com's Booking Now app for spontaneous or last-minute bookers, to priceline.com's Iowa Chat, to our Pay with OpenTable moment -- mobile payments app, to KAYAK's mobile itinerary management tools, innovation and execution on mobile is entered D&A and critical to the group's continued success.
Across the group, our customers completed over 100 million reservations from their smartphones in the last 12 months and that number continues to grow very rapidly. 
We believe the group's business performed well in the first quarter and we're pleased with the progress of our brands and growing and improving their platforms. 
Our fundamental growth momentum as measured by units and in constant currency, remains strong. We again, delivered strong organic performance on both the top and bottom line, providing substantial earnings to reinvest in profitable growth and share buybacks while maintaining attractive operating margins.
We repurchased $309 million of our common stock during the quarter, and have a remaining authorization of $2.8 billion remaining for future quarters. 
I believe it strongly as ever that our formula of out innovating the competition, smart and sustainable organic growth, and earnings versus buying our customers loyalty through best-in-class consumer experiences end-to-end and across devices, is the winning long-term formula.
I commend my colleagues around the world for their focus and execution. I will now turn it over to Dan for a more detailed summary of our financials.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Darren. I'll discuss some of the highlights and operating results and cash flows for the quarter, and then provide guidance for the second quarter of 2015.As we highlighted when we gave guidance for Q1 in February, our U.S. dollar reported resul
componenttext:
Thanks, Darren. I'll discuss some of the highlights and operating results and cash flows for the quarter, and then provide guidance for the second quarter of 2015.
As we highlighted when we gave guidance for Q1 in February, our U.S. dollar reported results are impacted more dramatically by extreme currency volatility than most companies because about 90% of our full-year 2014 gross bookings and operating income were generated by our international brands.
Our 2 most impactful currencies, the euro and the British pound, grew weaker by about 18% and 9%, respectively, for Q1, as compared to the prior year. The euro was also about 2% weaker, compared to the rate assumed in our Q1 guidance.
The strong U.S. dollar means our gross bookings, gross profit, operating expenses, adjusted EBITDA and non-GAAP net income, mathematically translate into significantly fewer dollars than they would have at last year's exchange rates for Q1, Q2 and the remainder of the year.
Since our expenses are denominated in foreign currencies on a basis similar to our revenues, they will also translate into fewer dollars. Therefore, our operating margins are not significantly impacted by currency fluctuations, and we believe that the impact of currency on our bottom line is generally similar to the top line impact.
However, due to our normal business seasonality, the bottom line currency impact is somewhat less pronounced in Q1 than the top line impact.
Although the stronger dollar has a significant negative impact on our growth expressed in dollars, the fundamental performance of our business is still evidenced in our unit growth rates and our growth rates expressed in constant currency for gross bookings, international gross bookings and gross profit.
Q1 was a strong quarter for Priceline Group. Accelerating unit growth, paired with less margin pressure than forecasted resulted in over performance compared to consensus, at both the top and bottom line. 
Room nights growth was strong relative to Q4 across all our key regions. Room nights booked grew by 25% in the first quarter, accelerating slightly, compared to the 24% growth rate for Q4. Rental car days grew by 18% in Q1, also accelerating compared to Q4, growth of 16%. Average daily rates for accommodations, or ADRs, for Q1 2015 were up on a constant-currency basis by about 2% for the consolidated group. 
Q1 gross bookings grew by about 26% on a constant-currency basis, and by about 12% in U.S. dollars, compared to the prior year.
International gross bookings grew by about 29% on a constant-currency basis, and by about 14% in U.S. dollars. 
Gross bookings for our priceline.com brand business in the U.S. grew by 2%. Similar to recent quarters, the results are a mix of solid growth in retail room nights and rental car days, offset by declines in Name Your Own Price services, which continue to be challenged by a lack of discounted rates.
Gross profit for the quarter was $1.7 billion, and grew by about 32% on a constant-currency basis, and by 19% in U.S., compared to prior year. 
Our international operations generated gross profit $1.4 billion, which grew by about 30% on a constant-currency basis, and by 15% in U.S., compared to prior year. 
Gross profit for our U.S. operations, including OpenTable's U.S. business, amounted to $277 million, which represented 38% growth versus prior year. OpenTable generated worldwide revenue in Q1 of about $61 [ph] million.
Non-GAAP operating income amounted to 31.1% of non-GAAP gross profit for Q1, which is 448 bps lower than last year. 
As I said when we gave guidance for the quarter, we are investing in OpEx in people, offices and IT capacity, to build up the capability of the business to handle future growth. 
Q1 also reflects deleverage from the inclusion of OpEx for OpenTable and our BookingSuite of hotel marketing services. Online advertising also had de-leveraged due to lower ROIs and gross bookings acceleration that benefits revenue in Q2 and Q3, when eastern summer travel takes place.
Investments in OpEx and advertising typically have a more pronounced impact on profitability in Q1, when we earn a lower percentage of our annual gross profit due to the normal seasonality of our business.
Operating margins did come in better than our guidance, however, due mainly to lower than forecasted nonadvertising OpEx. 
Adjusted EBITDA for Q1 amounted to $532 million, which exceeded the top end of our guidance range of  $510 million, and represents 4% growth versus prior year.
Non-GAAP net income grew by 3%, including interest expense from our recent bond offerings, and non-GAAP EPS grew by 4%. 
In terms of cash flow, we generated approximately $209 million of cash from operations during the first quarter 2015, which is about 18% above last year.
We invested $31 million in CapEx, and repurchased 251,000 shares of our common stock for $309 million in Q1. We expect to execute the remainder of our $3 billion common stock buyback program going forward to return capital to shareholders at a pace that makes sense relative to available cash in the U.S. and potential other uses for such capital.
We completed 2 successful financing transactions in Q1 at attractive interest rates. We raised EUR 1 billion for our U.S. parent company, by offering a 12-year bond in Europe at a 1.8% interest rate. We also raised $500 million, by issuing a 10-year bond in the U.S. investment grade market with a 3.65% [ph] interest rate. 
Our cash and investments amounted to $9.6 billion at March 31, 2015, with about $2.5 billion of that balance in the U.S. 
Now for Q2 guidance. The travel market continues to be fundamentally healthy from an occupancy and ADR perspective, broadly and in Europe. We are pleased with the resilient unit growth that our business has delivered historically, and is inherent in our Q2 forecast. Our guidance assumes that our growth rates will decelerate for the quarter due to the size of our business.
Our Q2 forecast assumes foreign exchange rates of $1.12 per euro and $1.51 per British pound for the remainder of the quarter, which would result in average exchange rates that would be weaker by about 19% for the euro, and about 11% for the British pound, as compared to the prior year. As a result, our gross bookings, gross profit, operating expenses, adjusted EBITDA and non-GAAP net income, will mathematically translate into significantly fewer dollars than they would have at last year's exchange rates for Q2 and the remainder of the year.
Borrowing further deterioration in exchange rates, we believe that Q2 represents our toughest year-over-year currency comp for 2015.
For Q2 guidance, we are forecasting total gross bookings to grow by 15% to 22% on a constant-currency basis, and by 0 to 7% in U.S. dollars, with U.S. gross bookings growing by about 0 to 5%. 
We expect international gross bookings to grow by 17% to 24% on a constant-currency basis, and by 0 to 7% in U.S. dollars. 
Our Q2 forecast assumes that local currency ADRs for the consolidated group will be up by less than 2% compared to the prior-year period. We expect the Q2 revenue to grow year-over-year by approximately 0 to 7%, and gross profit to grow by 17% to 24% on a local-currency basis, and by 1% to 8% in U.S. dollars. 
We expect that declines in our Name Your Own Price service will continue to negatively impact revenue growth rates in Q2.
We expect about 550 bps of de-leverage in non-GAAP operating margins, compared to prior year, expressed as non-GAAP operating income as a percentage of gross profit.
Q2 forecast reflects the impact of investing in OpEx to add people, offices and IT capacity to build up the capability of the business to handle future growth. Q2 also reflects OpEx for OpenTable and our BookingSuite of hotel marketing services. 
While we are not giving you earnings guidance beyond Q2, we do expect pressure on operating margins from nonadvertising OpEx to significantly diminish over the back half of the year as we lap the OpenTable acquisition and the launch of our BookingSuite initiative.
Our Q2 advertising forecast assumes lower online ad ROIs and increased investment in offline advertising, including rolling out campaigns in new markets. 
Our approach to advertising spend is consistent with our past approach. We invest in a manner that we believe is sustainable over the long-term, with the goal of building our brands with consumers. We then strive to win the loyalty of our customers by giving them the most choices and the best booking experience across all devices they use to search and book.  This approach has resulted in the nice balance between top and bottom-line growth, and loyal customers that overtime, are increasingly coming to us directly, rather than through paid channels.
Our adjusted EBITDA is expected to range between $716 [ph] million and $765 million, which is the midpoint, is a decrease of 9% versus prior year. 
As I mentioned a moment ago, we estimate the currency impact on EBITDA growth is similar to impacting for gross profit. Adjusted EBITDA growth this also impacted by de-leverage in operating margins just discussed.
Our non-GAAP EPS forecast includes an estimated cash income tax rate of approximately 15%, comprised of international income taxes and Alternative Minimum Tax and state income taxes in the U.S. The non-GAAP EPS forecast also reflects the dilutive impact of a full quarter of interest expense from the bond offerings we did in Q1, without any assumed share repurchases we may make using the proceeds.
We are targeting non-GAAP fully-diluted EPS of approximately $10.95 to $11.75 per share, which of the midpoint is, a decrease of 9% versus prior year. Our non-GAAP EPS guidance assumes a fully-diluted share count of 52.8 million shares, based upon yesterday's closing stock price. 
We forecast GAAP EPS between $8.85 and $9.65 per share for Q2. The difference between our GAAP and non-GAAP results is driven by non-GAAP adjustments that are detailed in our earnings release.
Consistent with past practice, we have hedge contracts in place to substantially shield our second quarter EBITDA and net earnings from any further fluctuation in the euro and British pound versus the dollar between now and the end of the quarter. The hedges do not offset the impact of translation on our gross bookings, revenue, gross profit or operating income. They also do not hedge us against fluctuations in other currencies, and do not hedge our earnings beyond the second quarter, although we remain concerned about economic conditions in general, and our forecast does not assume any further deterioration in macroeconomic conditions.
We will now take your questions.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Justin Post with Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Justin Post with Merrill Lynch.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: When you look at your bookings guidance for 2Q, it looks pretty healthy and consistent with Q1, but it does seem like gross profit is decelerating x FX, and could you just talk about the dynamics there? And then as you look at the marketing de-leverage, a
componenttext: When you look at your bookings guidance for 2Q, it looks pretty healthy and consistent with Q1, but it does seem like gross profit is decelerating x FX, and could you just talk about the dynamics there? And then as you look at the marketing de-leverage, are you seeing a really -- pressure on ROI or what's really driving that, is it mix, mix of businesses or what's really driving that?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Dan, do you want to take that?
componenttext: Dan, do you want to take that?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hey, Justin. So in terms of gross profit, we're seeing very healthy performance there. The impact of OpenTable is a little bit more significant in Q1, the inorganic impact, just given the normal seasonality of our travel businesses. And in terms of the on
componenttext: Hey, Justin. So in terms of gross profit, we're seeing very healthy performance there. The impact of OpenTable is a little bit more significant in Q1, the inorganic impact, just given the normal seasonality of our travel businesses. And in terms of the online advertising forecast, ROIs are the key driver there. We don't go into all the building blocks behind what are putting the pressure on the ROIs. But it's a story we've been telling you now for a couple of years. And we saw ti in Q1, and we're forecasting it to continue in Q2.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mark Mahaney of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mark Mahaney of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Darren, I think you mentioned that Agoda bookings showed acceleration, could you give any more color on what's happening there, and also, talk about the China outbound market in -- to the extent that it's building up in materiality?
componenttext: Darren, I think you mentioned that Agoda bookings showed acceleration, could you give any more color on what's happening there, and also, talk about the China outbound market in -- to the extent that it's building up in materiality?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So why don't I -- thanks, Mark. The first of all, the way I think about Agoda is more broadly, how things are going in Asia. And as you know, we have 2 big brands in Asia: Agoda and Booking.com. And together, we have a really strong business. Agoda h
componenttext: Yes. So why don't I -- thanks, Mark. The first of all, the way I think about Agoda is more broadly, how things are going in Asia. And as you know, we have 2 big brands in Asia: Agoda and Booking.com. And together, we have a really strong business. Agoda has traditionally been a business in South East Asian bookers, but it's really expended nicely to include a lot of North Asian bookers and Oceana. At the same time, Booking.com, which started the European business, has had a lot of success expanding into Asia. And really, the real strength of the 2 brands is in -- Asians moving around Asia. So you have a lot of movement right now, between China and Japan, Taiwan and Japan, Korea and Japan, there's a lot of movement also, Australia going to Southeast Asia. Southeast Asia is going to North Asia. So we've participate then in a lot of the movement within Asia. And both brands continues to grow and have a lot of success. China, specifically, is an amazing market. We have our relationship with Ctrip. We are constant meeting with the team. I've just got back from China. I met with James and Jane, and it's turning out to be a great partnership. Our Outbound business with them is up quite significantly year-over-year. That said, we have more work to do still. We have an onboarded Ctrip's inventories as fast as I'd hope. There are a lot of issues that we're working through. We're also exploring the need to ramp up our own efforts in China to bring on inventory.  And also, Ctrip is not our only in a relationship with China. We've got a lot of deep partnerships with various other sources of demand. So we're very bullish. I believe the group is really leading an independent travel outbound from China. I mean, most Chinese do atill travel in packages. But over time, that's going to change, and I think we're in a really nice position in that specific market, which is going to be likely in the next 5 to 10 years, the largest outbound market in the world. And we're making sure that we're serving it, as well as we can.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Tom White with Macquarie.
componenttext: Our next question is from Tom White with Macquarie.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Dan, could you maybe just clarify a bit about, some of your comments around FX impact on EBITDA in 1Q? It sounds like, maybe it was less impacted due to FX, and I'm just kind of curious. Does that sort of reversed, or how does that play into the 2Q guidan
componenttext: Dan, could you maybe just clarify a bit about, some of your comments around FX impact on EBITDA in 1Q? It sounds like, maybe it was less impacted due to FX, and I'm just kind of curious. Does that sort of reversed, or how does that play into the 2Q guidance? And then just quickly, on the European competitive landscape, one of your competitors is seemingly making concessions on their take rates, hotel take rates in Europe to get more competitive. Are you guides are seeing any signs that that's impacting your ability to, I guess, get share of rooms, forgiven properties? And maybe just comment on how badly maybe your international hotel partners, do they need additional sources of distribution, generally?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Dan, why don't you take the first one. I'll take the second one?
componenttext: Dan, why don't you take the first one. I'll take the second one?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Hey Tom. So on that first question, we'll you be the specific calculation for the impact of currency on the top line, both for gross bookings and gross profit. It's easy for us to precisely calculate -- well, not easy. But we can precisely calculate
componenttext: Sure. Hey Tom. So on that first question, we'll you be the specific calculation for the impact of currency on the top line, both for gross bookings and gross profit. It's easy for us to precisely calculate -- well, not easy. But we can precisely calculate that because we know the currencies that all of those, bookings and gross profit, are generated in. It's a little bit more difficult at the bottom line, because particularly, online advertising, we're making various assumptions, as to the currencies, that some of the key words would pertain to. What we determined based upon our estimates, is that generally, the impact of the bottom line is similar to what we're quantifying for you at the top line. In Q1, the impact is not as dramatic, because just seasonally, less of our earnings are denominated in euros in Q1. So it's about 14 percentage points at the gross profit line, you can assume it's something less than that at the EBITDA line.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And Tom, on your question on competition in Europe. We haven't seen any specific impact. We really set the low bar on take rates. And as we've continued to grow in Europe, I'm sure there's a lot of pressure on our competitors. It's hard to --  let's
componenttext: Okay. And Tom, on your question on competition in Europe. We haven't seen any specific impact. We really set the low bar on take rates. And as we've continued to grow in Europe, I'm sure there's a lot of pressure on our competitors. It's hard to --  let's say, commissions, let's start with the 2, in Europe, when we're -- everything we have starts with the 1.  But we're really the ones setting the standard. And I think there's probably -- competitors have to match that, if they're going to ultimately get access to availability. We've always believed that any hotel, any partnership have a various sources of demand. We don't cover every customer base in the world. So we would encourage them to use channel managers, have all the sources of demand that they can find. But, of course, we want to fill our fair market share of those rooms. So I don't see anything, specifically, that's coming from that, rather than just probably, a long-overdue balancing, rebalancing of the market, as it relates to take rates. But our business here -- I've just got out of the market in Europe, it's very healthy in our position, I feel very good about.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Stephen Ju of Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question is from Stephen Ju of Crédit Suisse.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Darren, from a unit, growth of units sold perspective, rental car days, you stopped pace the growth to your hotel room nights. So -- but more recently, that has slowed. It seems like that should be a less online penetrated sector in travel, so the grow
componenttext: So Darren, from a unit, growth of units sold perspective, rental car days, you stopped pace the growth to your hotel room nights. So -- but more recently, that has slowed. It seems like that should be a less online penetrated sector in travel, so the growth rate should be higher as a result. So can you help us reconcile what may be going on? Is the supply a lot more constrained, or is online penetration a lot harder than we think?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks, steven. No, I don't think I would take either one of those conclusions. Because in both cases, even though I believe, we're likely the leaders in rental car bookings in the world online, among independent parties and certainly, the same on h
componenttext: Well, thanks, steven. No, I don't think I would take either one of those conclusions. Because in both cases, even though I believe, we're likely the leaders in rental car bookings in the world online, among independent parties and certainly, the same on hotel room nights, in either one, we're such a big player, that it reflects either one market maturing fast than the other. It's largely our own execution. I am actually, review proud of the acceleration we're now seeing in rental cars. In particular, our rentalcars.com business, as we've talked about before, it used to be a very opaque model. And last summer, we went to a transition to make it much more retail, so adding reviews, adding brands. And that was a lot of work, but we feel really good how we've come out of that transition, and really improved our direct business, their loyalty, much more of -- let's call it a Booking.com approach, to rental cars. And we're quite excited about the momentum, but I don't think that the market specifically. Neither one of them are we reaching any kind of the feeling on the potential, and really how fast and how hard can we execute to get to the ultimate potential of the business.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just one other point, I'll add, Steven. Our retail unit growth for rental car days is much healthier than the consolidated growth rate that we quote. So Name Your Own Price rental cars are down year-over-year because of lack of availability of discoun
componenttext: And just one other point, I'll add, Steven. Our retail unit growth for rental car days is much healthier than the consolidated growth rate that we quote. So Name Your Own Price rental cars are down year-over-year because of lack of availability of discounted prices. So the growth rate for retail is more similar than what you're seeing with the hotel business.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Eric Sheridan with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question is from Eric Sheridan with UBS.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe 1 big picture topic for Darren. Given your continued comments around marketing de-leverage, and I appreciated the color around direct versus paid. How do you think longer term back directly about more business to direct channel versus the variable c
componenttext: Maybe 1 big picture topic for Darren. Given your continued comments around marketing de-leverage, and I appreciated the color around direct versus paid. How do you think longer term back directly about more business to direct channel versus the variable channel? And how much you accomplish that, and how much mobile might fit into that, as you evolve over the next couple of years?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, thanks, Eric. Yes, at the very highest level, our business is becoming more direct. And that's also allowing us to lean into paid channels more. What we like is the combination of online marketing, as well as our offline marketing. It's helpin
componenttext: Okay. Well, thanks, Eric. Yes, at the very highest level, our business is becoming more direct. And that's also allowing us to lean into paid channels more. What we like is the combination of online marketing, as well as our offline marketing. It's helping to build our brands. And we always judge things on the base of earning positive ROI in the transaction. So if I can give positive ROI in the transaction, and there's enough opportunity to do that, we're going to lean into it. That's like fishing, where you're going to fish and then you actually have to work with the customer to make them loyal over the long-term. So that rhythm, in our entire business, is working very well. Obviously, the more direct business you have, at some point, is an end game, where you are completely direct. But often, that obviously, dramatically improve the market economics. But we're not at that time, and we're still very much having the search out more and more customers to bring on to the platform. So that's one area. I don't know, Dan, if you want to make a comment as well on marketing?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. I'd say the same thing. I mean, there's a slightly that some business forever, will come through to us through a paid channels. So many people just use Google as their entry point to the Internet, and with metasearch players and Tripadvisor, just havi
componenttext: No. I'd say the same thing. I mean, there's a slightly that some business forever, will come through to us through a paid channels. So many people just use Google as their entry point to the Internet, and with metasearch players and Tripadvisor, just having very strong brands, too, that some customers probably will always prefer to start there. But we like the trends that we see in terms of people continuing to increasingly come to us directly.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And then your second part to your question was on mobile. Obviously, there's a lot of talk -- if you get somebody on a mobile app, then there is the panacea, because then their entry point to the Internet is always through you, and it's a very valuab
componenttext: Yes. And then your second part to your question was on mobile. Obviously, there's a lot of talk -- if you get somebody on a mobile app, then there is the panacea, because then their entry point to the Internet is always through you, and it's a very valuable customer. But to get people on your mobile apps, marketing spend.  But also, there's a large chunk of business that still happen through mobile web. And we're a big partner of, in particularly, Google but other search engines and meta-engines. And I feel really good about our mobile web product performs. So I don't think there's a place specifically in our business. We're not a high-frequency thing like a Facebook or a Twitter. So our business is never going to end up being 100% app. And there's always going to be a nice balance between web and app. I should say and a couple of exceptions to that in the portfolio, OpenTable is very happy app, because of the nature of a restaurant reservation. Actually, KAYAK is a very heavy app, because people are always checking fight schedules. It's a much more frequent occurrence than actually, going out and booking a hotel room or renting a rental car.  And that's why mobile web, by the way, performs a lot like a desktop web. It's a different product you're buying, but you're holding to a similar ROI standard and spending as well.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Naved Khan of Cantor Fitzgerald.
componenttext: Our next question is from Naved Khan of Cantor Fitzgerald.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you talk a little bit about the vacation rentals business, and how many related [ph] to the acceleration in room nights?
componenttext: Can you talk a little bit about the vacation rentals business, and how many related [ph] to the acceleration in room nights?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, okay, Naved. So we're really -- I'm very happy with the progress there. We -- as I mentioned, we're now over 275,000 properties. I always like to remind people of the way we count properties, is I would count in the part hotel as a property, or a blo
componenttext: Yes, okay, Naved. So we're really -- I'm very happy with the progress there. We -- as I mentioned, we're now over 275,000 properties. I always like to remind people of the way we count properties, is I would count in the part hotel as a property, or a block of apartments. We actually have over 1 million rentable units. So we actually have a very competitive supply relative to others in the market. Our vacation rental business, we don't have a number to announce. We talked about -- maybe each year, we'll talk about that. But I will say, it's growing faster than our core business. It is a product that's very demanded by our customer base. And we feel like our tools and our various rhythms are getting better and better at ingesting this kind of stock. We have a lot of innovations now we're working on to get to the single owner, single property market, which is a whole new market that we have in, as today, we've been addressing as well. Most of our vacation rental homes are through property management companies. So there's a large segment of the market where the home owner actually manages their home. So really excited about it, it seems to -- our customers seems to want the product, which obviously, is important, and to balance out the supply and the demand side. And we're going to continue to push there and innovate in the coming months, quarters.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Mike Olson with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question is from Mike Olson with Piper Jaffray.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: You mentioned Priceline brand domestically, is facing some hundreds right now, especially in the opaque business, which makes sense. But you have 2 new management of that brand to try to revitalize growth. But could you talk more specifically about how th
componenttext: You mentioned Priceline brand domestically, is facing some hundreds right now, especially in the opaque business, which makes sense. But you have 2 new management of that brand to try to revitalize growth. But could you talk more specifically about how the Booking.com brand is doing in the U.S. and how the initiative to grow that brand domestically is maybe, comparing to your expectations at this point?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, okay, Mike. So we don't really specific numbers. But generally speaking, if you dig around and you ask the average U.S. hotel, they would generally say, we're the fastest-growing of the players. We're growing off of a smaller base. We're trying all s
componenttext: Yes, okay, Mike. So we don't really specific numbers. But generally speaking, if you dig around and you ask the average U.S. hotel, they would generally say, we're the fastest-growing of the players. We're growing off of a smaller base. We're trying all sorts of things in the U.S. For us, it's a big growth market, because we're just starting -- we're under indexed in the U.S. And it seems like, it takes time that the market is also sticking with the American customer base. So we're excited. It's a super high priority in my list. The Booking.com model works particularly well in really small countries that don't speak English, and people who move around countries. And for us, we generally under indexed in really large countries, where people don't leave the country.  And that's where our growth -- one of the angles of our growth potential. So that's why we focus so hard on China, Japan, United States, even Germany, to really work on getting that domestic book base as well. And so far, so good. But, like everything in this business, it's a lot of hard work and a lot of small steps, and we continue to invest and push forward in the U.S. market.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Douglas Anmuth with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question is from Douglas Anmuth with JPMorgan.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Dan, can you talk a little bit more about the spending and the profit guidance for 2Q? And you obviously pointed out the lower ROI for advertising, as you have for several years now. But is there a difference in the marketing strategy in this 2Q versus in
componenttext: Dan, can you talk a little bit more about the spending and the profit guidance for 2Q? And you obviously pointed out the lower ROI for advertising, as you have for several years now. But is there a difference in the marketing strategy in this 2Q versus in the past? And how do we think about how much impact yours coming from OpenTable and BookingSuite spend, and I know you, of course, you're not guiding for the rest of the year, but can you just comment on how you're thinking about that more in the back half?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Doug. So spending for Q2, starting off with other OpEx, nonadvertising. You get a sense from what you see in Q1, or what you can expect in Q2, and then pressure should subside, as we move beyond that, we lapped the OpenTable acquisition. In terms of
componenttext: Sure, Doug. So spending for Q2, starting off with other OpEx, nonadvertising. You get a sense from what you see in Q1, or what you can expect in Q2, and then pressure should subside, as we move beyond that, we lapped the OpenTable acquisition. In terms of advertising, no change in our -- said that the prepared remarks. So we've been very consistent all the way through. One thing that is different in this quarter is that there was more of a ramp in offline spend, so some markets that we've introduced recently, France, for one, Germany which we launched in the back half of last year, it's in our spending in Q2, this year against no spend in last year. And we'll be looking to grow that into additional markets as well which you'll see as we proceed through the quarter. So that's having more pressure on Q2 margins than it did on Q1.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Ross Sandler with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question is from Ross Sandler with Deutsche Bank.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just 2 questions. One, sticking with the marketing, on the offline campaign, can you talk about the impact that this is having on the overall business? I guess, how many countries you're in right now? And are you seeing any improved efficacy with your onl
componenttext: Just 2 questions. One, sticking with the marketing, on the offline campaign, can you talk about the impact that this is having on the overall business? I guess, how many countries you're in right now? And are you seeing any improved efficacy with your online in the countries where you had the TV going for some period of time? And then the second question is around the newer hotel software business, Buuteeq plus the other pieces. So can you just talk about the strategy around this area? Is the goal to improve the transaction side of the business, or could this get meaningful stand-alone business within the group?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, Ross. So first of all, the offline, again, this is just the Booking.com statement. The markets we're in right now are U.S., Canada, Australia, the U.K., Germany and France. And the way we think about it is -- obviously, we have a lot of micro-data,
componenttext: Okay, Ross. So first of all, the offline, again, this is just the Booking.com statement. The markets we're in right now are U.S., Canada, Australia, the U.K., Germany and France. And the way we think about it is -- obviously, we have a lot of micro-data, so we're trying everything we can to measure the effect and unless you're running an ad on this channel versus that channel. And we built a great team that can optimize the way we spend our advertising relative to the bookings, against that advertising. So when you get to the macro level, the goal is to hit in a return an advertising standard that adds both our online spend and our offline spend. And of course, what you want to do is have a high return on that total spend, as you begin spending offline than you did when you only spend online. So you always get a combination of more and more of your business coming direct, but also an improvement in your online spend because people might click on your ad because they have -- last saw you in television when -- they might not click on your ad because they're like, who are these guys?" And we -- so even measuring that. It usually takes some months to figure out, to a year end, to a positive ROE territory. And with almost every market, so far, we've proven that we can get to positive ROA. Maybe not always in 12 months, but we can ultimately, get to positive ROA. And that's what encourages us. It doesn't mean we can spend offline today, and tomorrow our ROA is higher than it was before, because it doesn't happen that way. That's the big challenge with offline marketing. But more or less, we now have enough experience to know that that macro metric is getting to where want to do it. And that's why we continue to lean in the market. And ultimately, the ROA improves because of the clicking. But again, we're getting more and more direct business. BookingSuite. So the play there, there's 2 sides to it. One is building a SAS business. We're -- this is a Software business. And we think because we already have a sales force in place, which is the toughest thing in a SaaS business of distribution, that's were all the costs go. So we have a sales force in place. So we can have specialists sit as our sales first quarter, so we can go out and talk to many, many hotels everywhere in the world, and have a set of specialists help with that.  But we also already have a lot of hotel content. We have the availability, we have the booking engine, so we can build a hotel side very fast, with almost no variable cost. And that's why the BookingSuite product is basically free, the base product. And then we earn money out of the transaction. And we've done all of our modeling that that'll be a good material business for the group. I don't see it, likely it ever being bigger than our core transaction booking business. But it's a sizable business on its own. The other side of the reason of doing BookingSuite, is helping our partners become more capable with technology. And the more capable they are with technology and keeping their calendars up-to-date, keeping their pricing right, the more able they are to plug-in to our platform. And a third thing, but it really is a third, is that we can do all of this and save our partner's money, and they can then trust us more as a company, that we do more than just building transaction. We're actually make it easier to run a property. That's another benefit. .So it's really threefold, but we're not just doing this to be nice. It's a real business, and we expect in the, let's call it, the medium to longer-term, to have a pretty substantial impact on our overall business.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ron Josey of JMP Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ron Josey of JMP Securities.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask you on the pricing parity clauses, I think the agreement this quarter with the EU. Do you have like hotels now somewhat more controlled on inventory availability while requiring the same price. I'm just wondering, what's changed and what t
componenttext: I wanted to ask you on the pricing parity clauses, I think the agreement this quarter with the EU. Do you have like hotels now somewhat more controlled on inventory availability while requiring the same price. I'm just wondering, what's changed and what the potential impact could be? And then a quick follow-up, on just Ross' question, around the, around BookingSuite. I know -- you said at launch this quarter, and the medium, long term, could be bigger. But where are you in sort of -- at launch, but what does that mean? Is the sales force selling it, that will be helpful.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay, Ron. So first, on the parity clause, we're pleased with the outcome. We wouldn't propose it otherwise. For us, parity is not a construct of the online market, the online industry. It's  actually the whole travel industry. Like, if you had to g
componenttext: Okay. Okay, Ron. So first, on the parity clause, we're pleased with the outcome. We wouldn't propose it otherwise. For us, parity is not a construct of the online market, the online industry. It's  actually the whole travel industry. Like, if you had to go to a site that's sold the Delta Airline ticket, and it was always $10 more, it's hard to be in business. Apple has the same thing. If you go buy a Mac in an Apple Store, and then you go to a third party distributors and it's $10 more, there won't be any third-party distributors. So parity is a very important construct, that levels of playing field, it allows us to really reach our primary objective. Our primary objective is to always make sure that our customers get the best price. Like we can't be in businesses, if our customers feel that they're paying more using any of our assets. So we worked this -- through this compromise, I think it was well understood by the authorities, that there's a free writing problem in a business like ours, if our suppliers, who basically, load their prices on our systems. And load the higher prices on our systems, and lower price on their system. But more importantly, regardless of whether there's parity or not, if the hotel is on our system, and the price are too high, it won't convert. And if it doesn't convert, then it won't show up, because there's a ranking mechanism anyway, that always makes sure that the best product moves at the top. And our best partners have the best product, have a very strong incentive to give our customers good value, because our customers won't buy things that aren't good would value. So there's already a really strong reinforcing element. I don't see this as having any significant impact on our business, but it's a moving target. There's always new discussions and things. But the way that our business runs and the reason customers use our products, they want to have confidence that we're getting the best pricing. And this agreement doesn't, at all, affect our rights or ability to make sure that they get the best price, and that's what's important. And then on the BookingSuite topic, we don't, we don't release right now how many sites we're putting out. Maybe in a few quarters, we'll give everyone an insight into that, but it's off to a very strong start. So it's promising. The team in Seattle, which was Buuteeq, is our back-end team. And we now have sales people out in the field. They're really a second-tier sales force. They're not in every office, but they're there. When a warm lead happens, it gets handed off to somebody who really knows the depth of what they're talking about. We're in the bigger countries. But in the smaller countries, we're just getting to that. Our teams are just getting trained up on that. So it's sort of a rolling motion, but early signs are very, very positive. And the demand for the product, it's extremely strong, which is a good feeling, because it shows our partners trust us, and they recognize that this value proposition is really outstanding for people who have a website in the accommodation arena.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Heath Terry with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question is from Heath Terry with Goldman Sachs.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Darren, I was hoping you could kind of give us a bit of an update on how you're thinking has evolved about the lifetime value of mobile app customers? I know on the conversation -- questions you've asked before, you've generally talked CPAs as the primary
componenttext: Darren, I was hoping you could kind of give us a bit of an update on how you're thinking has evolved about the lifetime value of mobile app customers? I know on the conversation -- questions you've asked before, you've generally talked CPAs as the primary value that you're driving towards, driving your ROI towards. I'm wondering if -- as you've learned more about the way mobile customers act on apps and have a better understanding of sort of cross-platform attribution, if the way that you're thinking about mobile app acquisition or customer acquisition relative to that LTV has changed?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, Heath. Thanks. Yes, what we find is, at least, in our business. And this is now more of Booking.com, or go to rental car statement. But put aside, KAYAK and OpenTable because of the aforementioned, that they're primarily on app, and they get the sor
componenttext: Okay, Heath. Thanks. Yes, what we find is, at least, in our business. And this is now more of Booking.com, or go to rental car statement. But put aside, KAYAK and OpenTable because of the aforementioned, that they're primarily on app, and they get the sort of the really high repeat frequency type customers, which is a different set of behaviors. But in our business, our most loyal customers is a bit of a circularity, because our most loral loyal customers are the one to carry the app. And our most loyal customers are the ones that bounce overall the screens. So the app, for them, is not just a booking experience, it's the thing that they carry their reservation in. We know how travel guides. So the travel guide is in the app. When they check into a hotel, immediately, it says, "Are you happy or sad?" So all of these things come with the app and help our most loyal customers that are often -- the people who book with us already many times, they continue to repeat with us. So it would be a stretch to say that everyone who uses the app is a more loyal customer, because the input to that, generally, is some more loyal.  But we do find generally now, going away from app and talking about mobile more generally. The move -- the biggest thing that's changed in our business is the move from a single screen world, where you only did one thing with us, which was make a booking, to a multiscreen world, where you have an end-to-end experience from looking to booking to enjoying your trip on the ground, is giving us more and more loyalty. So people realize there's lots of reasons to use our products. But when they can actually, make the whole experience better, people see that wow, this is just a better way to do things. And it's hard to make that multiscreen experience all tied together. And we're certainly not complete with that work. But it's a huge differentiator. And for a big player like us, we have the assets and the resources to invest to make that seamless, and for you to be able to do that anywhere you travel in the world. This isn't an easy work, by the way, because all of these softwares don't naturally speak with one another. When you've got to get the right cloud-based architecture, where your account can sit in the cloud, and no a matter if you're on the app, or Booking Now, are you on an AppleWatch, or you're on the website that your account immediately gets tied together. But that's work the team has done, and I think, does reward the bigger players who can really plumb that new sort of end-to-end multiscreen digital experience for our customers. So I'm excited. For e-commerce players, mobile is a real positive. When you're in the media business, mobile has this extra tradeoff, that it's just harder to convert something through media on a smaller screen and that's obviously -- you're seeing that trade-off between those who own the transaction and those who don't.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Kevin Kopelman with Cowen and company.
componenttext: Our next question is from Kevin Kopelman with Cowen and company.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Could you talk broadly, about how you're thinking about margins and the vacation rental business, compared to hotel booking? And is there any difference in how you approach ROA for that business?
componenttext: Could you talk broadly, about how you're thinking about margins and the vacation rental business, compared to hotel booking? And is there any difference in how you approach ROA for that business?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, Kevin, yes, we -- so first of all, if you start up with hotels and then below hotels, there's a whole collection of things, that you could call self-catered products. So first, just commenting on B&Bs and apartments, and things like that, we s
componenttext: Okay. Well, Kevin, yes, we -- so first of all, if you start up with hotels and then below hotels, there's a whole collection of things, that you could call self-catered products. So first, just commenting on B&Bs and apartments, and things like that, we see that the commission levels and the take rates in that space are equivalent to the hotel space. We don't feel any extra pressure. We -- again, that's always the lands that we have a very low bars as it is around the world, compared to most of our competition, but we don't feel pressure to go lower. When you get into the single vacation home space, we still have generally signed up without having to dilute our take rate much. So there's a little bit more pressure there, because the average vacation home owner, it's a marketplace with a lot of friction and a lot of uncertainty. And we're the first and only transaction engine that works that's instantly verifiable. So our property has actually has a calendar that works. There's no back and forth with the consumer, like once the customer buys, then they have to pay. So there's a lot of work still yet to be done. And a lot of these players are used to marketing themselves through a classified ad or on an Internet website. And they're expecting phone calls, or maybe, if -- some of them may even be on Airbnb. And there's just different economics in that, that I would say that, the story is still out on the vacation home market. But at we've, at least to-date, approach it in a similar way. The other argument of vacation homes is, the length of stay there is a lot longer, the ADR is potentially, higher. And therefore, they would argue that the take rate percentage would be lower, but the absolute take rate is actually very healthy relative to the booking. But sorry, long answer to the question. I don't feel a lot of pressure, but in the vacation home, single-owner market, we, of course, will compete aggressively as we need to, and be smart about the economics.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015

componenttext: I've got 2. The first of this just to go back to the gross profit guidance in 2Q, and then what we saw in the first quarter. It looks like constant gross profit per room night, if I back up OpenTable, was about up 1% year-on-year versus 4% last year. Is that geomix from Agoda or is there something else going on that we should make sure we consider in our 2Q modeling? And then a higher level one. As you talk about strategies to drive more direct business, any thoughts about offering a broader loyalty program for Booking.com, or how do you think about loyalty programming at this point?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, Dan, why don't you take the first, I'll take the second.
componenttext: Okay, Dan, why don't you take the first, I'll take the second.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So Brian, our gross profit relative to room nights, the room nights are on as booked basis, and the gross profit is on a stayed basis. So you've got a little bit of a mismatch there. We've had a strong quarter with accelerating growth, and to not a
componenttext: Sure. So Brian, our gross profit relative to room nights, the room nights are on as booked basis, and the gross profit is on a stayed basis. So you've got a little bit of a mismatch there. We've had a strong quarter with accelerating growth, and to not a insignificant degree, those checkouts are going to occur in Q2, around Easter, and then Q3, around summer. And the other factor is, as I mentioned before, OpenTable has a more dramatic inorganic benefit to Q1, because of the travel businesses are just seasonally smaller in that quarter. And so that's gross profit, it's in our numbers with no room nights associated with it.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Brian, on loyalty programs, generally, so we do have a couple in the group. Agoda has a loyalty program, although we're slowly phasing that out. OpenTable has a points loyalty program. This is in the more traditional earned points, earned nights, get
componenttext: And Brian, on loyalty programs, generally, so we do have a couple in the group. Agoda has a loyalty program, although we're slowly phasing that out. OpenTable has a points loyalty program. This is in the more traditional earned points, earned nights, get things free. We -- booking.com, specifically, we believe that, that kind of mechanism for the really infrequent traveler, can be as much of a turnoff as a turn-on, because they may only do 2 bookings a year, but they may be want is do 1 booking, and then maybe do it quite infrequently. And for them, what they want, is just to create experience. So we focused -- to drive loyalty we focus very much on the product, and getting them amazing pricing. When you go to a destination, it's not about what this hotel cost, it's about, what is the selection and assortment allow me to buy. And our users love the fact that they could find that place that directly matches what they need at a great value. And that's what's driven our loyalty over time, is really been product experience. That said, Brian, I can tell you, we haven't book 5x on Booking, because if you do within a year, we have a program called Genius, that we offer more of a surprise and delight fashion to our most frequent guests. And that allows them access to other closed user group rates that are supplied by our hotel partners. Our hotel partners are really interested in our most frequent guests, improves their conversion, and therefore, improves their placement on our front-end to all customers. And that's something we've had in the market now going on a couple of years and has been really successful. So that's been our approach to-date. It's not that we won't change that. We're always questioning these things. Rocket Miles, we bought, it's a really interesting small company in Chicago that uses airline miles. That's more -- we're interested in it, because it's a real fast-growing, very unique business. But we're obviously, now bringing in some people with some deep expertise within Rocket Miles. Many of them came from the Airline Frequent Flyer Miles business. And we'll see if we learn anything from that that might impact our thinking differently in the future.

componenttextpreview: As you look at room night growth, up 25% year-over-year, how much of that growth has driven by new properties, let's say, properties that have been in the platform for less than a year, and how much of the growth has been driven by all the properties?
componenttext: As you look at room night growth, up 25% year-over-year, how much of that growth has driven by new properties, let's say, properties that have been in the platform for less than a year, and how much of the growth has been driven by all the properties?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Manish, I'll take that. So we don't devolve that specifically, but it's a higher level, I shared this before. That if you are property on Booking.com 5 years ago, on average, every year, we've given you more bookings. So if you're a brand-new proper
componenttext: Okay. Manish, I'll take that. So we don't devolve that specifically, but it's a higher level, I shared this before. That if you are property on Booking.com 5 years ago, on average, every year, we've given you more bookings. So if you're a brand-new property, you come on. And that's always been our goal, is to have enough demand, so that all of our existing properties don't feel like we're taking business away from them, but they continue to get more, and we can also feed our new properties. When we look at our property growth, that the 40% we talked about, the properties are getting smaller and smaller on average. It's not that we're not signing up big hotels, big resorts. But on average, that's getting smaller. So our unit growth in terms of bookable properties, is not growing at the pace of our business, which therefore, allows us to continue to keep our property partners happy, is the way to think about it.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015

componenttext: Got it. And then can you comment on the recent correlation of the space? And what should we expect your response to be, especially in markets, where you're under indexed versus the global travel market share?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we -- well, as I said on the last call, we think the consolidation clarifies competition. It's not the strategy we're following. And we've ad we continued to stay focused on what we're good at, and I -- it's -- even if the 3 players are now 1 player,
componenttext: Yes, we -- well, as I said on the last call, we think the consolidation clarifies competition. It's not the strategy we're following. And we've ad we continued to stay focused on what we're good at, and I -- it's -- even if the 3 players are now 1 player, we have the same strategy in the United States, as we always had. It hasn't changed our product, it hasn't changed our value proposition and we continue to push forward and I would say quite successfully. And by the way, say that not saying the other strategy is bad, it's just different than what we've been doing. And the space that we occupy is very large, it has been said many times. But that $1 trillion or $1.3 trillion, even if you had our largest competitor, with us, we still make up less than 10% of the opportunity. So it's not like we're running against one another every day. It's more our segment of the business which is online travel, largely independent travelers, people leveraging the Internet, is as a nice tailwind behind it. And we're making sure that we do our best to capture as much of that as possible.
