The Priceline Group would like to remind everyone that this call may contain forward-looking statements, which are made pursuant to the Safe Harbor provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future performance, and are subject to certain risks, uncertainties and assumptions that are difficult to predict. Therefore, actual results may differ materially from those expressed, implied or forecasted in any such forward-looking statements. Expressions of future goals or expectations and similar expressions reflecting something other than historical fact are intended to identify forward-looking statements.
For a list of factors that could cause the group's actual results to differ materially from those described in the forward-looking statements, please refer to the Safe Harbor statements at the end of the group's earnings press release, as well as the group's most recent filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Unless required by law, The Priceline Group undertakes no obligation to update publicly any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
A copy of the group's earnings press release, together with an accompanying financial and statistical supplement, is available in the for investors section of the Priceline Group's website, www.pricelinegroup.com.
And now I'd like to introduce The Priceline Group's speakers for this afternoon: Darren Huston and Daniel Finnegan. Go ahead, gentlemen.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you very much, and welcome to The Priceline Group's second quarter conference call. Thank you for joining us before the market's opened this morning in New York. I'm here in Amsterdam, with Priceline Group CFO, Dan Finnegan.The group reporte
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you very much, and welcome to The Priceline Group's second quarter conference call. Thank you for joining us before the market's opened this morning in New York. I'm here in Amsterdam, with Priceline Group CFO, Dan Finnegan.
The group reported consolidated gross bookings for the second quarter of approximately $15 billion, up about 26% on a constant currency basis, or about 11% year-over-year in U.S. dollars. Our customers booked the accommodation reservations for 113 million room nights in the quarter, up 26% year-over-year, reflecting slight acceleration for the second consecutive quarter.
Non-GAAP earnings per share were $12.45, down slightly versus prior year, surpassing FactSet consensus estimates of $11.85 per share and our guidance for the quarter.
Our U.S. dollar-denominated growth rates were again, impacted substantially by the strong dollar. Our International business recorded 30% gross bookings growth on a constant currency basis, up from 29% last quarter. Booking.com continues to benefit from further penetration of its existing partner relationships, as well as growth in its accommodation supply. Booking.com's platform now has about 707,000 hotels and other accommodations, and 220 countries and territories, up 35% over last year, including 313,000 instantly bookable vacation rental properties.
Vacation rental properties grew 62% year-over-year, and now represent 1.7 million rentable units within these properties. In the last 12 months, the most 50 [ph] million room nights for vacation rental properties were booked on Booking.com and villas.com, up 39% year-over-year. This quarter, we began experimenting with self on-boarding of individually-owned vacation rentals properties, subject, of course, to set of quality checks on our side, and the ability of the property to be instantly bookable.
We already have an encouraging pipeline in of vacation rental properties to activate via this channel. And we're hopeful that this functionality will help us scalar property acquisitions even further.
BookingSuite, our partner-facing software services platform, is off to an impressive start, and continues to exceed our expectations, with the strong demand in streamline execution by our teams. We also added to our BookingSuite offering in Q2 with the acquisition of PriceMatch, a simple cloud-based tool that uses big data to our partners improve their properties' production to enhanced revenue management.
International results also benefited from Agoda.com and rentalcars.com. Agoda delivered a solid quarter consistent with Q1, with special attention to the question of private sales deals that logged in customers. Strong momentum continued at rentalcars.com, which accelerated for the fourth quarter in a row, furthering its lead stover's largest dedicated site for multi-supplier rental car reservation.
Priceline.com continues to be a tale of two cities, with strong regional performance, offset by its shrinking, but still large Name Your Own Price business. The priceline.com management team is making targeted investments, as part of its plan to drive innovation into its business, and to solidify its position as the best site for travel deal in North America.  There's a new level of energy at the company, and we expect great things in the coming quarters.
KAYAK delivered an exceptional bottom line performance in the quarter, which exceeded our expectations, will OpenTable continue to produce double-digit domestic diner growth. After some amount of work to transition its underlying B2B and B2C infrastructure, it's on track to begin launching new international markets later this year.
We took some steps in the quarter to further expand our growth in Latin America. Booking.com launched a TV advertising campaign in Brazil while the group invested $60 million in a minority stake in Hotel Urbano, one of Brazil's largest and fastest-growing online travel companies. Our investment includes an exclusive commercial partnership, whereby, we will provide a Hotel Orbano customers access to the combinations outside of Latin America. 
Finally, and importantly, it's worth commenting on mobile. It is difficult to overstate the importance of this trend. Today is a group, about 1 of 3 buckets of hotels, rental cars and restaurants, happens on a mobile device. At current run rate, this will be more than half of our business in only 2 to 3 years. On a Sunday, in just a week back, we completed a 300,000 transactions, gross of cancellations on mobile at Booking.com for the first time. All of our brands are investing heavily in making our products relevant to consumers across all their screens in a connected fashion, and in ways that are industry-leading.
Since the end of Q1, we repurchased about $1.35 billion of our common stock, and have an authorization of $1.4 billion remaining for the future quarters.
The group performed well in the second quarter on both the top and bottom line. We'll continue Booking.com's successful foray into brand advertising in certain international markets, and investors aggressively in online global channels to profitably build our booking business for the seasonally strong third quarter. We remain committed to striking the right balance between top line growth and bottom line profitability, and you will see, in particular, more stability in non-advertising OpEx percentage, in the second half as we anniversary the OpenTable and BookingSuite investment.
We believe we are making the smart and sustainable investments today that will extend our lead as the world's largest online travel business for years to come. We'll also delivering healthy returns for our shareholders today.
I want to thank our employees around the world for their hard work and dedication.  I will now turn it over to Dan for a more detailed summary of our financials.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Darren. I'll discuss some of the highlights in operating results and cash flows for the quarter and then provide guidance for the third quarter of 2015.We've talked the last couple of quarters about how significantly our U.S. dollar reported res
componenttext:
Thanks, Darren. I'll discuss some of the highlights in operating results and cash flows for the quarter and then provide guidance for the third quarter of 2015.
We've talked the last couple of quarters about how significantly our U.S. dollar reported results are impacted by extreme currency volatility, because about 90% of our gross bookings and operating income are generated by our international brands.
Our 2 most impactful currencies, the euro and the British pound, grew weaker by about 19% and 9%, respectively, for Q2, as compared to the prior year. Many other important currencies in which we transact, were also significantly weaker versus the U.S. dollar in Q2 relative to last year.
The strong U.S. dollar means our gross bookings, gross profit, operating expenses, adjusted EBITDA and non-GAAP net income, mathematically translate into significantly fewer dollars than they would've at last year's exchange rates for Q2, Q3 and the remainder of the year.
Since our expenses are denominated in foreign currencies on a basis similar to our revenues, they also translate into fewer dollars. Therefore, our operating margins are not significantly impacted by currency fluctuations, and we believe that the impact of currency on our bottom line is generally similar to the top line impact. Although the stronger dollar has a significant negative impact on our growth expressed in dollars, the fundamental performance of our business is still evident in our unit growth rates and our constant currency growth rates for gross bookings, international gross bookings and gross profit.
The Priceline Group performed well through all of these key metrics in Q2. Accelerating unit growth, paired with less margin pressure than forecasted, resulted in overperformance compared to consensus at both the top and bottom line.
Room night growth was strong in Q2 across all our key regions. Room nights booked grew by 26% in the second quarter, accelerating slightly compared to 25% growth rate for Q1. Rental car days grew by 20% in Q2, also accelerating compared to Q1 growth of 18%. Average daily rate for accommodations, or ADRs for Q2 2015, were up on a constant currency basis by about 2% for the consolidated group.
ADR trend expressed in U.S. dollars would obviously look significantly worse based upon the currency dynamics I just discussed.
While we are the midst of this period of extreme currency volatility, our growth expressed in constant currency, gives a truer picture of our fundamental business performance. It is more in line with what you would expect based upon our strong unit growth and constant currency ADRs growth.
Specifically, our Q2 gross bookings grew by about 26% on a constant currency basis, but by only about 11% expressed in U.S. dollars compared to prior year due to the stronger dollar. Similarly, international gross bookings grew by about 30% on a constant currency basis, and by only about 12% expressed in U.S. dollars. Gross bookings for our U.S. business grew by 1%. 
Similar to recent quarters, the U.S. results are a mix of growth in retail room nights and rental car days, offset by declines in Name Your Own Price services. In addition, lower airfares impacted retail air gross bookings growth, but have no impact on gross profit.
Gross profit for the quarter was $2.1 billion, and grew by about 26% on a constant currency basis, and by 11% in U.S. dollars compared to prior year. Our international operations generated gross profit of $1.8 billion, which grew by about 26% on a constant currency basis, and by 8% in U.S. dollars compared to prior year. Gross profit for our U.S. operations, including OpenTable's U.S. business, amounted to $303 million, which represented 32% growth versus prior year. OpenTable generated worldwide revenue in Q2 of about $62 [ph] million.
Non-GAAP operating income amounted to 37.3% of gross profit for Q2, which is 469 bps lower than last year. Online advertising grew faster than gross profit due to lower ROIs, and gross bookings acceleration that partly benefits revenue in Q3 when summer travel takes place. 
In addition, as we've highlighted over recent quarters, we are investing in OpEx to add people, offices and IT capacity to build up the capability of our core travel business to handle future growth. Q2 will also reflect the leverage from the inclusion of OpEx for our OpenTable and our BookingSuite of hotel marketing services, which are currently in investment mode as we invest to plant seeds for future growth.
Operating margins were, however, better than our guidance due mainly to lower-than-forecasted non-advertising OpEx. Adjusted EBITDA for Q2 amounted to $805 million, which exceeded the top end of our guidance range of $765 million, and represents a 1% decrease versus prior year, reflecting the significant foreign currency translation impact with the stronger U.S. dollar.
Non-GAAP net income decreased by 2%, and non-GAAP EPS decreased by 1%, including interest expense from our recent bond offerings of the beneficial impact of lower share count from stock repurchases.
In terms of cash flow, we generated approximately $702 million of cash from operations during second quarter 2015, which is about 2% above last year, and is also impacted by unfavorable foreign exchange rate translation. We invested $53 million in CapEx, and repurchased it 720,000 shares of our common stock for $849 million in Q2. Thus far in Q3, we repurchased an additional 436,000 shares for $500 million.
We expect to execute the remaining $1.4 billion of our $3 billion common stock buyback authorization at a pace that makes us, and based upon the price of the which our stock is trading available cash in the U.S. and potential uses for other -- other uses for such capital.
Our cash and investments amounted to $9.6 billion at June 30, 2015, with about $1.9 billion of that balance in the U.S.
During Q2, we entered into a new $2 billion revolving credit facility to replace our existing facility, which was expiring next year. The facility is a 5-year term, and provides us with significant additional financial flexibility at a reasonable cost. 
Now for Q3 guidance. The travel market continues to be fundamentally healthy from an occupancy and ADR perspective broadly and in Europe. Our room night growth has been remarkably resilient, ranging between 24% to 27% over the last 4 quarters. Our guidance reflects another strong quarter of growth, but assumes that our growth rates will decelerate, mainly due to the size of our business and consistent with long-term trends.
Our Q3 forecast assumes foreign exchange rates of $1.09 [ph] per euro and $1.56 per British pound for the remainder of the quarter, which would result in average exchange rates that would be weaker by about 18% for the euro, and about 7% for the British pound as compared to the prior year. 
I highlight that the euro exchange rate is worse than the $1.12, that prevailed when we last recorded and most analysts updated the forecasts. As a result, our gross bookings, gross profit, operating expenses, adjusted EBITDA and non-GAAP net income will mathematically translate into significantly fewer dollars than they would've at last year's exchange rates for Q3 and the remainder of the year.  Barring further deterioration in exchange rates, we believe that year-over-year currency comes will become less challenging after Q3.
For Q3 guidance, we are forecasting total gross bookings to grow by 13% to 20% on a constant currency basis, and by minus 1% to positive 6% in U.S. dollars, with U.S. gross bookings about flat with the prior year.  We expect international gross bookings to grow by 16% to 23% on a constant currency basis, and by 0 to 7% in U.S. dollars. 
Our Q3 forecast assumes that constant currency ADRs for the consolidated group will be up by less than 2% compared to the prior-year period.  We expect Q3 revenue to grow year-over-year by approximately 1% to 8%, we expect gross profit to grow by 19% to 26% on a constant currency basis, and by 3% to 10% in U.S. dollars. 
We expect that declines in our Name Your Own Price services will continue to negatively impact revenue growth rates in Q3.  We expect about 160 bps of de-leverage in non-GAAP operating margins compared to prior year, expressed as non-GAAP operating income as a percentage of gross profit, which is a nice improvement from the margin pressure we have seen in the last couple of quarters.  The de-leverage is mainly attributable to assumed continued pressure for online advertising ROIs, but to a lesser extent than we saw in Q2.
As we indicated on the last couple of earnings calls, margin pressure from non-advertising OpEx diminishes significantly in Q3, and we expect that trend to improve further in Q4. Over the longer term, we expect that our non-advertising OpEx will generally grow more slowly than our gross profit, and we have source of operating leverage.
Our forecast implies a 52% operating margin for Q3. The strong operating margins for our business relative to our competitors positions us well to succeed over the long term in a very competitive market. 
Our adjusted EBITDA is expected to range between $1.425 billion and $1.525 billion, which at the midpoint, is an increase of 3% versus prior year.
As I mentioned a moment ago, we estimate that the currency impact on EBITDA growth is similar to the impact that we are forecasting for gross profit. Our non-GAAP EPS forecast includes an estimated cash income tax rate of approximately 15%, comprised of international income taxes, and alternative minimum tax and state income taxes in the U.S. 
We are targeting non-GAAP fully-diluted EPS of approximately $22.95 to $24.45 per share, which at the midpoint, is an increase of 7% versus prior year. Our non-GAAP EPS guidance assumes a fully-diluted share count of 51.6 million shares based upon yesterday's closing stock price, and reflects the beneficial impact of about $1.7 billion of share repurchases we have made, thus far, this year.
We forecast GAAP EPS between $20.84 and $20 -- $22.34 oer share for Q3. The difference between our GAAP and non-GAAP results is driven by non-GAAP adjustments that are detailed in our earnings release.
Consistent with past practice, we have hedged contracts in place to substantially shield our third quarter EBITDA and net earnings from any further fluctuation in the euro and British pound versus the dollar, between now and the end of the quarter. The hedges do not offset the impact of translation on our gross bookings, revenue, gross profit or operating income. They also do not hedge us against fluctuations in other currencies, and do not hedge our earnings beyond the third quarter. Our forecast does not assume any significant change in macroeconomic conditions.
One housekeeping matter. Darren mentioned the Booking.com's platform now has over 770,000 hotels and other accommodations, including 313,000 vacation rental properties. In September, we intend to adjust our methodology for reporting property counts, to include properties that are contracted with Booking.com but are not currently available to be booked on our side. 
For example, we will now include properties in our account that are temporarily unavailable on our site, because we fill all the rooms alloted to us, or the property is closed seasonally or for renovations. Under the new methodology, we would've reported about 767,000 properties, including about 353,000 vacation rentals. Our prior-year property count on a consistent basis, is about 549,000 properties, including about 206,000 vacation rentals. We believe this change will remove volatility from our property count reporting, and will reflect the more consistent count of our total active partner relationships throughout the year. This is a small but important adjustment, as we continue to add more and more of a long tail and sometimes, seasonal business.
We will now take your questions.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Eric Sheridan with UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Eric Sheridan with UBS.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Darren, I appreciated that the color on mobile, how big it's becoming inside the business. I wanted to know what you were learning as mobile came bigger in terms of where money is best spent on a marketing budget to earn insufficient ROIs in mobile? How t
componenttext: Darren, I appreciated that the color on mobile, how big it's becoming inside the business. I wanted to know what you were learning as mobile came bigger in terms of where money is best spent on a marketing budget to earn insufficient ROIs in mobile? How that might develop longer term? And also, Booking.com was mentioned on Facebook's earnings call as a new partner. You've talked about social media in the past and what that might mean as a marketing channel for Priceline Group. I want to know if we can get some updated thoughts there?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Eric. So I think it's a point on mobile to do this thing -- obviously, there's web-based mobile and there app-based mobile. And web-based mobile, still largely, and traditionally through Google and other search engine. And I have to give Goo
componenttext: Okay. Thanks, Eric. So I think it's a point on mobile to do this thing -- obviously, there's web-based mobile and there app-based mobile. And web-based mobile, still largely, and traditionally through Google and other search engine. And I have to give Google a lot of credit, that's working better and better for us, where our web-based mobile is highly converting, big-based transactions for us. And then in the hotel space, transactions are relatively infrequent, so a pretty significant percentage happen on web-based, particularly customers we've never seen before. Our app-based customers tend to be our more loyal customers. And the place that we built those is mostly from our own property sites. We do go out and buy app downloads, although app downloads don't tend to be very economic, because they often get downloaded and then not ultimately used, at least from that space. So this is basically, is the world of accommodation. It's very different for KAYAK and OpenTable, primarily because both of those businesses are a much higher frequency business. They're very heavily skewed to app. And the whole business of getting people to use the KAYAK app to check for flights or OpenTable to book restaurant, is another dynamic. And both of those businesses focus, heavier and can find their economics, and actually getting downloads, and building lifetime value to customers that are app-based. And those app-based downloads -- there's a little bit of that that comes from Google, but a lot has come from new places, like Facebook and other partners. On Facebook, specifically, we -- we've been generating most of our demand from basically research or travel. And travel includes everything from TripAdvisor, down to easyJet, and airlines and trains and other things. So we've always dreamed of a time, where we could access demand from any of these big horizontal audiences. Facebook is obviously one, Twitter is another. You can think of WeChat or any of these other things -- so just being -- or even the big portals, Yahoo!, MSN, those places. But we've always struggled. And I was quite skeptical, but I have to give Facebook a ton of credit. We're finally getting some good business out of Facebook. Most of it is remarketing or remessaging. And we've now talked with senior management at Facebook, about how do we get intent [ph] out of their network. And that's an area that both us and them, are focused on, into a degree crack the code on intent, would make Facebook a real real serious source of demand for us as a business. And obviously, as a performance marketer, that will be a big deal for Facebook as well. So I'm excited the progress we're making. They, they're investing a lot of time, energy into it, too, which I appreciate. And hopefully, by cracking another source of demand, it allows us to also -- to diversify where we spend our money to find hotel customers.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Mike Olson with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question is from Mike Olson with Piper Jaffray.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: So you mentioned strong continued growth in vacation rentals, and you're clearly putting some effort into that space. How would you describe, just in general, your strategy there, and how your partnership with HomeAway fits into that? And overall, what ki
componenttext: So you mentioned strong continued growth in vacation rentals, and you're clearly putting some effort into that space. How would you describe, just in general, your strategy there, and how your partnership with HomeAway fits into that? And overall, what kind of of reception are you seeing from travelers on -- them seeing vacation rental inventories, has there been any reaction from your hotel partners?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Mike. Well, first of all, we started out as being a hotel-only site, but it's been some years now that we've built out other forms of multiroom accommodations. And even in our old -- in the old Booking.com model, even said hotel reservations
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Mike. Well, first of all, we started out as being a hotel-only site, but it's been some years now that we've built out other forms of multiroom accommodations. And even in our old -- in the old Booking.com model, even said hotel reservations was their subsegment-tag. But starting even 4, 5 years ago, we started adding B&Bs, and we even have treehouses and igloos and stationary boats. And basically, other things that you could book. So for us, we went from being the world's largest online hotel player, to now, being the world's largest player in online accommodation. So moving into vacation rentals is a very natural thing for us. It's kind of going down the pyramid, and ultimately, getting into this self-catered product. And for us, we're building it out in an instantly bookable, verifiable way, which is very different than what say, a HomeAway or an Airbnb is doing. We've also focused a lot on making sure the customer experience didn't have all the friction. If you can think of booking a vacation home, and having put down a deposit, and having multiple e-mail exchanges, and not really knowing you've got the property, and not really having the trust. We're doing in a much more kind of a pure e-commerce way. Just trying to create it ultimately, like booking a hotel. And through that strategy, we've had obviously, take a lot of friction of that in the industry, and change the way that players think about that. And it's a lot of work because for a vacation rental owner, you've got to maintain additional calendar. You can't overbook people. When you say the place is available at a certain price, it has to sell at their price. But slowly, we're seeing the ice start to crack a little bit, and starting to see a real momentum. And this is a -- this is great news for vacation rental owners, because this market has a lot of demand and a lot of people -- really think of vacation rentals as an upgrade, like if you've got a family or your group. And you're say, going into Barcelona instead of getting like, 4 hotel rooms, you can get a vacation home on the beach. And you can make your own meals instead of going out to restaurants every night. So this is a very important addition to our business, but there's a lot more work to do. We do have some cooperation with HomeAway, but it's not near the extent that maybe, some of our competitors. And we're still talking there. We have a fairly high bar. We don't do on-request bookings. And for us, it has to be truly instant. It can't be "Okay, I'll let you know in 24 hours." That can't be counted instant. And that's just part of the issue -- just keeping a very high bar, and keeping our product very pure, so that it fits with our traditional book or base. And so far, so good, and I -- and we're only going to do more of it. There was a really a jump into a segment. It was more of an evolution down the accommodation pyramid, into the sort of the bottom of the pyramid, which are clearly millions and millions of single-owner property around the world booked in cities, on beaches, at ski resorts, et cetera. So that's the story there.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ken Zener with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ken Zener with Evercore ISI.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the bookings in the unit seemed quite strong, but the revenue bar shouldn't decline 6% or so over the prior -- versus the prior year. Maybe, you can just elaborate a bit more on that pressure. Give us a sense -- maybe how much of it relates to mix, as
componenttext: So the bookings in the unit seemed quite strong, but the revenue bar shouldn't decline 6% or so over the prior -- versus the prior year. Maybe, you can just elaborate a bit more on that pressure. Give us a sense -- maybe how much of it relates to mix, as far as the vacation rental expansion versus maybe, some of the competitive factors that you're seeing. And also, you mentioned that Google is performing better. And any thoughts that you can provide us on kind of the current booking functionality, and how you see that progressing?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll let Dan -- why don't you take the first one?
componenttext: I'll let Dan -- why don't you take the first one?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hi, Ken. So in terms of take rate, what you see in Q2 is an acceleration in the business, so a very strong gross bookings momentum, with a portion of those stays and the revenue taking place in Q3. So if you look at our Q3 forecast, you'll see kind of a r
componenttext: Hi, Ken. So in terms of take rate, what you see in Q2 is an acceleration in the business, so a very strong gross bookings momentum, with a portion of those stays and the revenue taking place in Q3. So if you look at our Q3 forecast, you'll see kind of a reversal of that trend, where now, the take rate is going up. So the gross profit growing faster than the gross bookings. So it's a timing issue. Our take rate -- our fundamental take rate on our transactions is very stable.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then your question because -- on question on Google, specifically, on booking functionality, what -- did you want to -- would you repeat that?
componenttext: And then your question because -- on question on Google, specifically, on booking functionality, what -- did you want to -- would you repeat that?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, just -- you mentioned that Google's performing better, and if you can maybe, just specify, is that just in terms of the traditional keyword buys, or are you getting more traction in terms of working through the listing ads? And do you have any though
componenttext: Yes, just -- you mentioned that Google's performing better, and if you can maybe, just specify, is that just in terms of the traditional keyword buys, or are you getting more traction in terms of working through the listing ads? And do you have any thoughts as they try to roll out booking functionality in the company you'd be interested in, or other?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes. I mean generally, our relationship with Google is very strong. They have some of their own challenges. I mean, it's an amazing business, but it's become less of a percent of our business over time. So we've been working with them across our enti
componenttext: Yes, yes. I mean generally, our relationship with Google is very strong. They have some of their own challenges. I mean, it's an amazing business, but it's become less of a percent of our business over time. So we've been working with them across our entire business. Of course, always first, focused on core search. What are the other things we can do to innovate, to get more out of core search. And we've seen some benefit, particularly, in mobile web, where we work together to try to get more out of a mobile web, and that's been, I think very successful. And we're also working with the YouTube team, and we're also doing a lot of work on retargeting. So Google, kind of sees us as one of their biggest advertisers in the world. And we're a very technically performance-driven people. So we were closer together to try to get more out of all the various Google engines. Very specifically, hotel price ads is Google's priced product. We don't love it because we would rather by BlueLinx. We don't need all the extra lifting. But we do understand. And we have worked a lot with the HBA team to make that a better product. I think when it started out, there were a lot of savings and things shown on HBA. They just weren't real savings. Generally, in there's a lot of challenges which showing customers things that they're saving, when the large majority of the time, they're not. It's exchange rates, people don't put taxes on et cetera. It's a real -- it's not the prettiest space. So we were tied with them to improve their product. And then recently, as you've mentioned, they've launched an instant book product. It's still very early on. We don't love instant book products either, because we have a really good process of taking cold customers, and turn them into paying customers. So anyone who creates a path would end up becoming a lower common denominator, because we think we have one of the best booking pass. We have an agency model -- we don't even need the credit card in many cases to do bookings. So we're working also with Google on that, not standing away from and saying, "Hey, is there a way to make this work?" -- for our businesses as well as what you're trying to achieve. So it's always been a close-open collaboration, but as I always say, we're going to put our money where its strategic. We're going to watch it really closely. And we have lots of options on where -- to spend out money, we look to continue to create more options to find hotel demand in the future.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Michael Millman with Millman Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Millman with Millman Research.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: The other night, Expedia indicated that the bulk of their profits comes from repeat customers. Could you talk about to what extent profits come from repeat customers?
componenttext: The other night, Expedia indicated that the bulk of their profits comes from repeat customers. Could you talk about to what extent profits come from repeat customers?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. You have to go across our brands, but we never reveal the exact percentages. But we have a very healthy repeat business. And I would say, across all of our brands, every single brand, a repeat business every year, gets stronger and stronger. A lot of
componenttext: Yes. You have to go across our brands, but we never reveal the exact percentages. But we have a very healthy repeat business. And I would say, across all of our brands, every single brand, a repeat business every year, gets stronger and stronger. A lot of that is related to the new multiscreen environment. A lot of that is related to -- we do a lot more business with signed in account. In the early days, when it was a singlescreen, you would do transactional business. And every time you book a hotel or a flight, you have to re-enter all your information. But once you have an account, we can store your credit card securely, we can store your name, and at least, to like 1-click booking. And as we've gone into a multiscreen environment, that advantage for an account holder goes up dramatically. If you've ever tried to book an airline ticket on a mobile phone and not have an account, you know what I'm talking about, it's not a pleasant experience. But once you have an account, we can fill the forms, so we can facilitate that. And then you can take your confirmation that maybe, you booked on your tablet, and you can show up at the rental counter with the confirmation on your phone. These are all positives that have driven to more increased repeat business and loyalty among our customers. And then our challenge becomes really and has been how do we bring more customers into the franchise, and that's what we used paid marketing for. But generally speaking, our direct business continues to increase, which gives a reflection generally, of repeat business.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And with new customers, Michael, we're running in paid channels of positive ROIs, so they're profitable, too. I don't know to what extent. May be other players take a lifetime value approach, and perhaps, are losing money on the new customers, with the ho
componenttext: And with new customers, Michael, we're running in paid channels of positive ROIs, so they're profitable, too. I don't know to what extent. May be other players take a lifetime value approach, and perhaps, are losing money on the new customers, with the hope of making money over time. That's not the case for us.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mark Mahaney with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mark Mahaney with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was going to ask 2 geographic questions. You called out Latin America a little bit more. Just some more color on how big that -- how material that region is for you -- maybe, a little bit more explanation of the investment in Hotel Urbano? And then any
componenttext: I was going to ask 2 geographic questions. You called out Latin America a little bit more. Just some more color on how big that -- how material that region is for you -- maybe, a little bit more explanation of the investment in Hotel Urbano? And then any comments on -- you didn't mention the China outbound market, anything you want to point out, as to how well that's doing, the past 2 [ph] materiality there?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Mark. Well, let me give, just maybe, a little bit of top line geo commentary. So first of all, in the second quarter, Europe has been very strong. The Eurozone and Southern Europe was a little bit of the ripple of the Grexit, in the coming ba
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Mark. Well, let me give, just maybe, a little bit of top line geo commentary. So first of all, in the second quarter, Europe has been very strong. The Eurozone and Southern Europe was a little bit of the ripple of the Grexit, in the coming back of Greece. But generally, Europe has been very solid this year. U.S. is strong for U.S. travelers, and China inbound. But generally, almost everyone else is a little -- going a little less in the U.S. because of the currency effect. And yes, China outbound have -- continues to be very strong for us, growing at very fast rate. Japan inbound, Taiwan inbound, very strong. Korean inbound, not so strong because of MERS, not something that gets a to talk a lot in the United States, it was a real overhang for us. But on the other hand, we had positive comps. Southeast Asia was a much calmer place in Q2 than it was last  Q2. If you remember the Malaysian Air crisis, the coup in Thailand, the burning of factories in Vietnam, there are all sorts of things going on, but that's been a positive from a comp basis. And so that's some quarterly commentary, geographically. But specifically, strategically, Latin America, we entered Latin America -- it start with the Booking.com ramp a number of years ago, starting in Argentina, moving to Brazil. I would say, this is a year where we've really had a breakthrough in Latin America. And we launched our TV ad in Brazil. But really, despite the fact that Latin America is not in the greatest economic health right now, and the 2 big engines, which is Argentina, and most specifically, Brazil, with all kinds of issues, but this is any year where we've really gotten great traction in market, maybe passed the tipping point. We have offices now across the regions, and that's a real positive. And I think if you go to Latin America now, our Asian brand awareness is quite high. Hotel Urbano, specifically, this is a -- it's actually a site that gets a tremendous amount of traffic but still, it's a bit challenged in converting that traffic. But it has a great management team. We've always been excited about the volume of audience that they have. It's largely built through social channels. And you can think of this as kind of a mini feature investments I mean, we've made an investment in the company, but it was really all fit to unlock the commercial opportunity. We're like, "Where can we help these guys win?" -- thus, participate a little bit in that upside. But the commercial opportunity is -- I wouldn't say, it's a make or break for Latin America, but it's a good-sized piece of business that will help bring the Latin American outbound travelers to the Rest of the World. I think it also -- it's a reflection of the strength of our portfolio. It's so global that these matchup should make so much sense, because the product converts well. It's a great product. It's all translated, and we can take an audience like this, help the Hotel Urbano monetize, but also, create a great commercial opportunity for us as well.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Heath Terry with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Heath Terry with Goldman Sachs.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Darren, you have talked in the past about your willingness to go down the ROI funnel a little bit further on the advertising side -- willingness to take dollars for $0.90, versus requiring $0.70, I think, is the way put it in the past. How much of that wi
componenttext: Darren, you have talked in the past about your willingness to go down the ROI funnel a little bit further on the advertising side -- willingness to take dollars for $0.90, versus requiring $0.70, I think, is the way put it in the past. How much of that willingness is what's driving the 25% or 26% FX neutral growth that you're seeing here, clearly well above sort of where the overall market's growing?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Actually, probably, the -- thanks, Heath. I should've probably be clear in damage as well. We don't lose money on the transaction level. So on our paid advertising, we have a pretty high bar.
componenttext: Yes. Actually, probably, the -- thanks, Heath. I should've probably be clear in damage as well. We don't lose money on the transaction level. So on our paid advertising, we have a pretty high bar.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I understand that.
componenttext: Yes, I understand that.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we don't really -- so we'll -- so I think what you're saying is we might go down and spend $0.90 to get $1, and therefore, make $0.10, right? And that's really our push on the paid advertising side. The thing that we go out a little bit on a limb
componenttext: Yes. So we don't really -- so we'll -- so I think what you're saying is we might go down and spend $0.90 to get $1, and therefore, make $0.10, right? And that's really our push on the paid advertising side. The thing that we go out a little bit on a limb in is our brand marketing. We now know that we can get a pretty good return on our brand marketing, but it may not happen immediately. But we've shown and overtime, in the markets we've been in for a while, that we can get a better return on our advertising when you add the brand marketing to our performance marketing, send the return we got on our performance marketing alone. And we've done a bunch to build it -- it's the whole bunch of data-driven tools to help us with our media mix. And that's helped us be smarter and data-driven about where and how we spend our brand marketing dollars. So we're building over -- whatever, now it's been a couple of years, some more and more confidence in our ability to appropriately spend our brand marketing dollars, which obviously, is a big growth potential for the company. I mean, Booking.com is not a household name. If you go to America, you'd mentioned OpenTable and KAYAK and Priceline before you'd mentioned Booking. And the ability for us to build the brand and have great performance marketing is still growth potential that's not ahead of us. And we've been working hard and methodically --methodically attack that. I would, our growth is truly sustainable growth because the trademark and we're spending is earning us profit. And all the direct business we're coming is earning us, of course, even more profit. So I don't feel like -- as opposed to some geographies, we have positive unit economics on every single transaction. And we've looked to improve that. And any incremental that were making and marketing, generally comes with positive EBITDA. So -- and we're always trying to get as far as we can to generate positive EBITDA and cash flow for our customers. But we're not worrying about the percentage of our P&L that gets taken up by marketing. And that's been our general philosophy. Some people may say, "Well, if you're that far, why don't you go a little bit further?" And that's always the balance that we're striking on what business do we bring, and do we really, truly understand the economics. But always, trying to be positive on a transaction by transaction basis.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Justin Post with Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Justin Post with Merrill Lynch.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Questions related to marketing. I think you said ROIs are proving in 3Q. Is that a result of all the brand spending, or are there some technology conversion changes that are helping you? And then secondly, a lot of commentary out there about Instabook, on
componenttext: Questions related to marketing. I think you said ROIs are proving in 3Q. Is that a result of all the brand spending, or are there some technology conversion changes that are helping you? And then secondly, a lot of commentary out there about Instabook, on Tridadvisor and Google, any commentary on your exposure to those channels, and what your thoughts are, especially with Google, maybe taking direct bookings over the next year, how do you think about that affecting Priceline?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So thanks, Justin. Dan, why don't you take the first one, and I'll take the second one?
componenttext: Yes. So thanks, Justin. Dan, why don't you take the first one, and I'll take the second one?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hi, Justin. So just to be clear, ROIs were still down year-over-year, but not to the same extent as they were in Q2. And then just to do the normal seasonality with more checkouts taking place in Q3 we've got a benefit there in the economics as well, rela
componenttext: Hi, Justin. So just to be clear, ROIs were still down year-over-year, but not to the same extent as they were in Q2. And then just to do the normal seasonality with more checkouts taking place in Q3 we've got a benefit there in the economics as well, relative to the acceleration that occurred in Q2. We're not going to go into the drivers, specifically, for you -- what's happening in the ROIs because of the sensitive and competitive nature. But Darren talked about the benefits of the offline advertising is driving in online. It definitely helps -- it reinforce our branded and make it better known, which helps click-through rates, it helps drive people searching for the brand. And then every day, we've got hundreds of people that are running experiments to improve conversion on our websites. So that's just a constant battle that our people are very talented and do a great job with. But on that, I just want to comment on those specific drivers.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, on your question on instant book, yes, it's a pretty tricky equation. And always, the question is, is your advertiser trying to be an OTA? And it's the most extreme, being an OTA is really hard work, like 3/4 of our people are in customer ser
componenttext: Yes. I mean, on your question on instant book, yes, it's a pretty tricky equation. And always, the question is, is your advertiser trying to be an OTA? And it's the most extreme, being an OTA is really hard work, like 3/4 of our people are in customer service. They're in the field, they're working property by property on pricing and on availability, and it's a business you have to do at scale. And most of them are media partners, make a lot of money out of. At TripAdvisor, we spend more than $1 million a day. So we have to find a place to spend our money. And we, of course, don't want to spend it with somebody who's planning on being an OTA. I don't believe that's really what TripAdvisor is try to do, but we have to make sure that whatever business we participate in, is a good business. And it's a business that we can ultimately, pay for that will repeat on our platform. So that's why there's a lot of discussion in this area. There's not like a big rainbow for anyone that's in the media business on the other side, because they get most of the economics for the transaction anyways. It's not like suddenly, this whole bunch more money there. In fact, all there is, is just a lot more costs. If you have to think of -- I could show you my inbox someday at some of the escalations I get of the dirty ocean in Cabo, beat the person who wants a refund, or the flying ant and -- these are -- the OTA business sounds very sexy, but in fact, there's a lot of manual work. And that's why there's only a few players who do this work, and do it at scale. And by the way, I saw Ctrip have been there as well. That's why they do it so well. They're got over 10,000 customer service agents to deal with this kind of stuff everyday. So we're being good partners. We're leaning in. I frankly, think that instant book path, ultimately, will prove to be cannibalistic. They may help a little bit on mobile, but that's all to be seen. So we're trying to be positive partners in the process, and trying to make sure that if that's the way our advertising partners are going, that we can design a path that is a good option for us, and where we can get good business off of it.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ron Josey with JMP Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ron Josey with JMP Securities.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow up on -- I know some prior questions around marketing. And Darren, I think you said, specifically now, I think 1/3 of traffic is mobile, could you see that gain of 50% over time? And as you sort of see the mix between online and off-lin
componenttext: I wanted to follow up on -- I know some prior questions around marketing. And Darren, I think you said, specifically now, I think 1/3 of traffic is mobile, could you see that gain of 50% over time? And as you sort of see the mix between online and off-line working together, I wanted to understand a little bit more how you think about, how brand advertising sort of evolves over time, and when do you think you can start bringing that back as brand awareness goes up?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that's a -- it's an excellent question. When you ultimately, do a transaction on mobile, it's a question of -- what other screens that the customer engage with you on? How do they get to know the brand? And then there's an issue, of course, o
componenttext: Yes. I think that's a -- it's an excellent question. When you ultimately, do a transaction on mobile, it's a question of -- what other screens that the customer engage with you on? How do they get to know the brand? And then there's an issue, of course, of "Can you -- do you have the force through your brand?" By having a stronger brand, you get more loyal customers who then therefore, go more app-based mobile versus web-based mobile. To me, at the highest level, I think of mobile as a huge positive for a company like ours. For many of our partners, it's tough enough to build a great website. They actually have a multiscreen experience that works within account, it's a very difficult thing to do. So that's why I think net is a positive. I don't think it necessarily drives a lot of incremental business for us, and a little bit, may be more last-minute. But it's really a shifting, in the way that people engage with digital assets. I -- I'm sure marketing mix will change relative to mobile. I talked previously that more and more business are coming direct. It's a bit of a chicken and egg. Some of that may be because our mobile business tends to be more direct than our PC-based web business. But again, I think it's all 1 customer, and it's all related to the fact that people are living multiscreen lifestyles versus singlescreen lifestyles, which I think, is a net benefit to us. And ultimately, I think it also leads to more direct account-driven traffic, versus purely off of the web transactional traffic. I think the -- I would I guess, the last thing I would say -- and you certainly see this in China, the impact of mobile, and how like Ctrip buys their demand. And we've learned so much from that relationship, and I always appreciate all the time we get with James and Jane. But it's amazing how they just buy traffic differently. There are a whole market places for apps. In China that exists, that don't exist in the Western world. And how they build that up is -- it's quite fascinating and amazing. And I think there's a lot of lessons for us to learn as this environment changes. But yes, most -- today, again, as I said before, most of our app downloads are from our own properties, which means, it would have to find that some other way. Like in the past, the more and more than you in a sticky way, obviously, that's great business for us, because it's always coming direct by definition, and it's very profitable.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Lloyd Walmsley with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Lloyd Walmsley with Deutsche Bank.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Last August, you guys gave us some disclosure around the trailing 12 months vacation rental bookings. I'm wondering if you could update that number or maybe, whether we should just use the 39% room night growth that you gave on that $4 [ph] billion base n
componenttext: Last August, you guys gave us some disclosure around the trailing 12 months vacation rental bookings. I'm wondering if you could update that number or maybe, whether we should just use the 39% room night growth that you gave on that $4 [ph] billion base number? And then I guess, as a follow-up, I'mcurious if you could just give us some color on how different you see demand for that space? So for example, a lot of people coming specifically to look for your properties from marketing campaigns and keywords, click-driven, specifically to VR, or is a lot of that also people kind of looking also at hotels, and kind of get a sense for how different that growth trajectory can be without cannibalizing the core, so any color you could give there would be great.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Dan, why don't you take the first, and I'll take the second.
componenttext: So Dan, why don't you take the first, and I'll take the second.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Lloyd, the reason we gave you growth rate and room night is because of the impact of currency on that metric as well. And so it wasn't useful really, to give it to you in U.S. dollars. So I would recommend that you use those 2 data points we gave
componenttext: Yes. So Lloyd, the reason we gave you growth rate and room night is because of the impact of currency on that metric as well. And so it wasn't useful really, to give it to you in U.S. dollars. So I would recommend that you use those 2 data points we gave you in your model to try and understand the size of that business.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And in terms of the vacation rentals, incremental or not, our general voice is -- first well, it's 1 customer, and either a customer is just a consumer or their business person and a consumer, and they take a number of trips every year. And every tri
componenttext: Yes. And in terms of the vacation rentals, incremental or not, our general voice is -- first well, it's 1 customer, and either a customer is just a consumer or their business person and a consumer, and they take a number of trips every year. And every trip has a different rationale. And if somebody gives a hotel book around 3 other trips, they may be on a trip with their family and become a vacation rental booker. We want to be able to provide all of those instances, and all of those scenarios through Booking.com so they become comfortable with that. Rather than in the past, I need a hotel, I go to Booking. And if I need a vacation rental, I go to company XYZ. The markets have traditionally been very different because of the nature of the markets were very different. But more and more overtime -- and I think we're partly shipping that, and I believe that ultimately going to be the outcome, the market gets a little mixed, because a person says, "Hey, I'm going to Barcelona or I'm going to Rio de Janeiro, and I need to find a place to stay." It's a very common question there -- is where am I going to stay. And relative to that scenario, we want to provide them an option. And that option -- by having more optionality in that, you can drive incrementality, because the person may not find find the right thing on a site that has a more narrow set of options. But on our broad set of options, maybe, they have a certain price range in the certain thing they're looking, we'll be able to satisfy that. Or, in a market like San Francisco or New York, if ADRs and hotels are really high, even business person ends up in an apartment. Or, if you got a big event on, like the World Cup or the Olympics, where everything gets sold out, having all this incremental supply, it offers more that the people can complete them. So I think about it today -- if today's market, is very different between the vacation rental buyer and the hotel buyer, overtime, that'll only coalesce to become more a similar market. Because all it is, is human beings looking for a place to stay. And I think that it's generally -- that's generally the case that we're seeing on our site. Now certainly, vacation rentals face are generally, bigger groups, they're generally, longer length of stay, slightly higher ADR, relative to good take rate. It's always fundamentals, they reflect the market of today. But I do believe that those things are continuing to change and I think it just like B&Bs, used to be a very different thing than hotels, I think over time, accommodations will become more similar than less similar, because it's the same customer.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Douglas Anmuth with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question is from Douglas Anmuth with JPMorgan.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Dan, I was hoping you could just provide some more color on the commentary on the nonmarketing OpEx in the back half, is this purely, just a question of lapping OpenTable and BookingSuite as -- or is there anything else going on there? And then also, can
componenttext: Dan, I was hoping you could just provide some more color on the commentary on the nonmarketing OpEx in the back half, is this purely, just a question of lapping OpenTable and BookingSuite as -- or is there anything else going on there? And then also, can you comment on the take rate environment, what you're seeing now?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Doug. So in terms of take rates, I've mentioned before, our take rates are very stable. If you look at our margin picture and in general, the different ways that our margins are impacted. Take rate, stable, also in terms of revenue, we are not aggre
componenttext: Sure, Doug. So in terms of take rates, I've mentioned before, our take rates are very stable. If you look at our margin picture and in general, the different ways that our margins are impacted. Take rate, stable, also in terms of revenue, we are not aggressively discounting out of our margins. So we're stable there. In terms of take rates, just with, what we believe to be one of the lowest cost of distribution alternatives for our accommodation partners. We feel like that's stable for the long run. And then in terms of advertising, we talked about -- off-line advertising over the long run, we should see stable to margin leverage there. As we end up spending in the markets we want to spend at the levels we want to spend, we could see pressure from a time to time as we enter new market or we increase our spending in the market. But over the long run, we should have leverage there. The online advertising is a big variable, it's very hard to predict. But the OpEx is much more under our control. And we've had a good track record there over many years. So we feel comfortable that over the long term, we can have operating leverage in that line item. For Q3 and Q4, it is largely that we're lapping the acquisition of OpenTable and the acquisitions we made in the BookingSuite area. But as we've seen from time to time in the past, we have some lumpiness in the investments that we make in the core business. So in the early part of the year, we typically ramp up our customer service teams, our hotel teams, to get ready for peak travel season, and then we see leverage in that line item. Over the long run, I think we'll continue to see leverage there.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our last question is from Kevin Kopelman with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Our last question is from Kevin Kopelman with Cowen and Company.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Could you just give us an update on the rate parity landscape in Europe, given the changes to your agreements with hoteliers there?
componenttext: Could you just give us an update on the rate parity landscape in Europe, given the changes to your agreements with hoteliers there?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Kevin. So the highest level, I think, for those who follow this, we worked with the competition authorities in France, Sweden and Italy, a kindred agreement on what we call A Narrow MSM, which basically, allows us to keep parity with the hote
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Kevin. So the highest level, I think, for those who follow this, we worked with the competition authorities in France, Sweden and Italy, a kindred agreement on what we call A Narrow MSM, which basically, allows us to keep parity with the hotel's website. And Expedia's also agreed to that. We've had a number of countries come out formally, Austria, Denmark, the same agree, as many others, informally have dropped their cases against us. We've got 1 challenge in France a lot of banning parity, which we weren't consulted on or anything, but we'll come in the SEC, we -- of course, we follow the law. But I think the basic bottom line to understand in this whole discussion, we will never charge our customers more. You can say it clearer, we will never charge our customers more. So we will adjust to whatever environment it is, and we'll make sure that we get the best pricing for our customer. And in some case, we have so much innovation we could do, to make sure our customers don't get shown prices that are uncompetitive. And that -- I don't believe the new law in France is good for consumers. I don't think it's good for the French tourism. I don't think it's good for small properties in France. I actually think it's quite negative, but it is what it is, and we will adjust our model. And our business in France is really strong, both from a booker's standpoint, as well as bookings coming into France. So if doesn't concern me too much, other than just a lot of time invested in this -- this whole area. And I strongly believe -- I mean, parity was an invention of the hotel industry. So I strongly believe it's a good way that all travel should be sold on a basis where customers don't spend too much time searching. And that they decide which channel from an agnostic standpoint, that they want to buy through. But we're more than ready to compete under any set of standards, and hope that the Narrow MSN will be accepted more broadly across Europe.

componenttext: Okay. I guess that's it. Thank you all for joining our conference call and look forward to speaking to you next quarter.
