componenttext:
Welcome to The Priceline Group's third quarter 2015 conference call.
The Priceline Group would like to remind everyone that this call may contain forward-looking statements, which are made pursuant to the Safe Harbor provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future performance and are subject to certain risks, uncertainties and assumptions that are difficult to predict. Therefore, actual results may differ materially from those expressed, implied or forecasted in any such forward-looking statements.
Expressions of future goals or expectations and similar expressions reflecting something other than historical fact are intended to identify forward-looking statements.
For a list of factors that could cause the group's actual results to differ materially from those described in the forward-looking statements, please referred to the Safe Harbor statements at the end of the group's earnings press release as well as the group's most recent filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Unless required by law, The Priceline Group undertakes no obligation to update publicly any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
A copy of the group's earnings press release, together with an accompanying financial and statistical supplement, is available in the for investors section of The Priceline Group's website, www.pricelinegroup.com.
And now I'd like to just The Priceline Group's speakers for this afternoon: Darren Huston and Daniel Finnegan. Go ahead, gentlemen.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you very much, and welcome to The Priceline Group's a third quarter conference call. Thank you for joining us before the markets opened this morning in New York. I'm here in Norwalk, Connecticut with Priceline Group CFO, Dan Finnegan.Let me
componenttext:
Well, thank you very much, and welcome to The Priceline Group's a third quarter conference call. Thank you for joining us before the markets opened this morning in New York. I'm here in Norwalk, Connecticut with Priceline Group CFO, Dan Finnegan.
Let me point out that due to technical difficulties at NASDAQ, our press release is only available under the Events and Presentations section of our website at pricelinegroup.com, should be over the newswire momentarily.
The group reported consolidated gross bookings for the third quarter of approximately $14.8 billion, up about 22% on a constant currency basis or about 7% year-over-year in U.S. dollars. Our customers booked accommodation reservations for over 115 million room nights in the quarter, up 22% year-over-year.
Gross profit was up 12% or about 29% on a constant currency basis. EBITDA was also up 12% to $1.6 billion.
Non-GAAP earnings per share was $25.35, surpassing FactSet consensus estimates of $24.21% and our guidance for the quarter.
Our U.S. dollar-denominated growth rates were again impacted substantially by the strong dollar, and this will continue into Q4, hopefully, abating on a year-over-year comparable basis as we head into 2016. Our International business recorded 25% gross bookings growth on a constant currency basis, reflecting Strong Momentum on Booking.com. Booking.com's performance benefited from further penetration of its existing partner relationships, as well as growth in its accommodation supply. Booking.com's platform now has over 820,000 hotels and other accommodations in 220 countries and territories, up 38% over last year.
Today, we are releasing data that shows how these properties represent a combined total of 21 million potentially bookable rooms. Of this number, 14.4 million are within our traditional hotel partners, 1.8 million are vacation rentals, for example, apartments, aparthotels, village, chalets and others self-catered products; and the remaining 4.8 million are our other the room unique properties, for instance, B&Bs, guesthouses, ryokans, riads, et cetera. Hopefully, this gives you a sense of the sheer scale of our accommodation platform, by far, the largest directly bookable accommodation flection in the world, and provides a better comparison to some of the other players in our space. And all of these different types of tooms are bookable with the least amount of friction on any platform, all without fees to consumers, and all with instant verification.
We're also helping guests find and book accommodation on Booking.com at unprecedented levels. Since Booking.com's inception in 1996, we have helped more than 1 billion guests find a place to say. And in just the last 12 months, 285 million guests stayed with us. Coincidentally, in 2015, OpenTable will also seat its 1 billion diners well. Two industry-leading double-sided marketplace platforms, providing scaled experiences for users all around the world.
Following our successful launch of BookingSuite, which continues to gain traction in the B2B arena, we recently introduced another important B2B innovation: Booking.com for business. This new offering is geared to both the business traveler and the travel organizer. Our tools and our organizers to link travelers to the company account without losing oversight or to book on their behalf. Spending in the manager budget filters and spending reports, all of the company's hotel reservations can be viewed and managed in 1 place. And best of all, all enrolled Booking.com for business travelers automatically benefit from our rewards program, including closed user group discounts and special benefits in over 100,000 select properties worldwide.
We were aware that Booking.com had become a popular service business travelers and wanted to create an offering that was more tailored to their unique needs. We have high hopes for Booking.com for business, and early results are very encouraging.
Booking.com's direct share of business also continues to grow, reflecting the solid retention of the loyal and satisfied customer base we've accumulated and nurtured over the past decade, as well as the on, off-line advertising were now conducting in 8 major markets around the world.  As our direct business grows, so too does our investment and online paid channels. We are always looking for new sources of demand and ways to diversify our marketing mix. We invest our money in channels where we believe we can build our brand franchise for the long-term, while also earning attractive ROI within the transaction.
Consistent with these tenets, we agreed to participate in TripAdvisor's instant booking platform. Our agreement includes the prominent branding and marquee potential we require to begin participation. As with all of our channels, we'll experiment and optimize with our partners with TripAdvisor, and expect to achieve healthy ROIs while being given the opportunity to bring new customers into our fold for the long-term.
We will also work to make adjustments in a similar instant booking paths we have with KAYAK, and are willing to work with other media owners who adopt similar principles that allow both the media owner and the advertiser an opportunity to promote differentiation in the branded offerings and to grow their businesses.  Testing on TripAdvisor is scheduled to go live this week, starting with a some small sample.
Let me also make a comment on China. First, we fully support the recent M&A activities, specifically regarding Elong and Cunard, led by our investment nacho partner Ctrip. We hope that these will ultimately lead to a more rational market environment inside China.
But outside of our Ctrip relationship, we're not standing still waiting either. For instance, we started 2015 with only 8,000 in China on Booking.com, and now lists over 25,000. We expect this to grow rapidly over time in part with Ctrip's assistance. As well, Chinese customer growth is exceeded the overall growth in our business for many quarters now, and the Chinese are now the primary Eenvoud nationality to many important destinations for us.  The case of China is a good reminder that travel is inherently a nonlocal business, so global scale combined with a win-win partnerships like  we have with Ctrip, are critical for our mutual success.
Some commentary now on the other brands of the Priceline Group. Priceline.com posted modest growth in hotel and rental car reservations and in overall gross profit. With new leadership, we have been busy repositioning and reinvigorating our namesake brand. And a critical platform migration of priceline.com is nearing its final phases, and the team is eager to start innovating in a faster pace as the new text our rolls out in early 2016.
Agoda also had a challenging quarter and was negatively impacted by the August bombing in Bangkok and various currency headwinds. No strangers to challenge, the Agoda team continue to innovate and all aspects of its business and launched in October substantially revamped a mobile app. We are also seeing positive results from recent work to integrate Booking.com agency inventory into Agoda.
Similarly, although we continue to see strong diner growth in OpenTable, the pace of innovation needs to be improved, and we've made a number of management changes as a result. In particular, Christa Corals, OpenTable's interim CEO, has done an outstanding job leading the team through this transition. We remain excited by the growth potential of OpenTable and are confident that the renewed focus will help us get on the right path to capitalize on this tremendous potential.
Moving on to the rentalcars.com and KAYAK. Book brands delivered strong quarters. Rentalcars.com posted solid unit growth despite a tough comp, while KAYAK made some important changes in the way it markets its business internationally and as a result, accelerated on both the top and bottom line.  The group performed well in the third quarter, and we believe our brands are taking the right actions to best maximize our share of their attractive and expanding online marketplaces. Booking.com has established clear global leadership in the online accommodations market, and we plan to continue to profitably invest to improve and extend our services and bring more consumers to our site.
Mobile execution remains a bright spot across our group, and we steadfastly adhere to our formula for earning our customer's loyalty to delivering best-in-class consumer experiences end-to-end and across devices.
I would like to thank our ample user of the road for their hard work and dedication, and delivering terrific performance during our peak summer season.
I will now turn the call over to Dan for the detailed financial review.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Darren. I'll discuss some of the highlights in operating results and cash flows for the quarter, and then provide guidance for the fourth quarter of 2015.Throughout 2015, we've seen the strong U.S. dollars significantly impact our U.S. dollar re
componenttext:
Thanks, Darren. I'll discuss some of the highlights in operating results and cash flows for the quarter, and then provide guidance for the fourth quarter of 2015.
Throughout 2015, we've seen the strong U.S. dollars significantly impact our U.S. dollar reported results, because about 90% of our gross bookings and operating income are generated by our international brands.
Our 2 most impactful currencies, the euro and the British pound, grew weaker by about 16% and 7%, respectively, for Q3 as compared to the prior year. Many other important currencies in which we transact were also significantly weaker versus the U.S. dollar this year in Q3 relative to last year.  The strong U.S. dollar means our gross bookings, gross profit, operating expenses, adjusted EBITDA and non-GAAP net income, mathematically translate into significantly fewer dollars than they would have at last year's exchange rates for Q3 and Q4.
Since our expenses are denominated in foreign currencies on a basis similar to our revenues, they will also translate into fewer dollars. Therefore, our operating margins are not significantly impacted by currency fluctuations. And we believe that the impact of currency on our bottom line is generally similar to the top line impact. 
The Priceline Group performed well through all these key metrics in Q3. Room nights about the grew by 22% in the third quarter, decelerating compared to the 26% growth rate for Q2. Rental car days grew by 13% in Q3 compared to Q2 growth of 20%.  Average daily rates for accommodations, or ADRs, for Q3 2015 were up on a constant currency basis by slightly less than 2% for the consolidated group. ADR trends expressed in U.S. dollars would obviously look significantly worse based upon the currency dynamics I've just discussed.
While we are in the midst of this period of extreme currency volatility, the fundamental performance of our business is still evident in our unit growth rates and our constant currency growth rates for gross bookings, international gross bookings and gross profit.  Specifically, our Q3 gross bookings grew by about 22% on a constant currency basis, but by only about 7% expressed in U.S. dollars compared to prior year due to the stronger dollar. Similarly, international gross bookings grew by about 25% on a constant currency basis, and by only about 8% expressed in U.S. dollars. Gross bookings for our U.S. business decreased by about 3%.
Similar to recent quarters, the U.S. results are a mix of growth in retail room nights and rental car days, offset by declines in our Name Your Own Price services. In addition, lower fares -- lower airfares significantly impact the gross bookings growth but have no impact on gross profit growth.
Gross profit for the quarter for The Priceline Group was $2.9 billion, and grew by about 29% on a constant currency basis and by 12% in U.S. dollars compared to prior year. Our international operations generated a gross profit of $2.6 billion, which grew by about 29% on a constant currency basis and by 11% in U.S. dollars compared to the prior year. 
Gross profit for our U.S. operations, including OpenTable's U.S. business, amounted to $335 million, which represented 22% growth versus prior year. OpenTable generated a total worldwide revenue in Q3 of about $65 [ph] million.  Excluding the beneficial $13.7 million impact of a favorable travel transaction tax ruling in Hawaii, U.S. gross profit grew by 17%.
Our gross profit take rates where broadly stable as they have been for quite some time now. We believe that our revenue margins have been sustainable due to our position as a lower cost distribution channel that drives significant demand to our accommodation partners.
Our highlight for the quarter was operating margin that exceeded our guidance and were slightly better than last year. Non-GAAP operating income amounted to 53.7% of non-GAAP gross profit for Q3. 
Margins benefited as our marketing teams did a good job driving traffic, with a nice balance between top line and bottom line growth. Margins also reflect the benefit of strong gross profit flow-through.
The combination of 29% constant currency gross profit growth with stable operating margins results in strong bottom line profit performance. Adjusted EBITDA for Q3 amounted to $1.6 billion, which exceeded the top end of our guidance range of $1.25 [ph] billion, and grew by 12% versus prior year, despite the significant negative foreign currency translation impact of the stronger U.S. dollar.
Non-GAAP net income increased by 10%, and non-GAAP EPS grew by 14%, including interest expense from our recent bond offerings and the beneficial impact our lower share count from stock repurchases.
In terms of cash flow, we generated approximately $1.3 billion of cash from operations during third quarter 2015, which is about 1% above last year, and it's also impacted by unfavorable foreign exchange rate translation. We invested $42 million in CapEx, and repurchased 985,000 shares of our common stock for $1.17 billion in Q3. Thus far in Q4, we have purchased about 400,000 more shares of our common stock for $520 million.
Year-to-date through Friday, total cash return to our shareholders is about $2.8 billion.  Our cash and investments amounted to $9.4 billion at September 30, 2015, with about $700 million of that balance in the U.S. 
Now for Q4 guidance. We often get questions from analysts and investors are trying to understand the size of the accommodation market and our share of remote reservations. Darren just pointed out that the accommodations on our websites have about 21 million rooms. We internally estimate our market share by multiplying this figure by 365, and then dividing the sum into our annual room nights. This math implies a mid-single-digit market share, which I believe, highlights the opportunity for us to continues to grow our share with existing partners while our supply teams also continue to aggressively add new partners.
Our quarter is off to a strong start, as is evidence in our guidance. Our guidance assumes that are growth rates will decelerate as we progress through the quarter, mainly due to the size of our business and consistent with long-term trends. We have not yet launched our recently announced the advertising placement on TripAdvisor instant book. We are confident that this will be another way for us to reach travelers in a branded fashion with reasonable ROIs.  Our forecast for the quarter assumes that TripAdvisor instant book will not have a significant impact in our top line growth or at efficiency.
Our Q4 forecast assumes foreign exchange rates of $1.07 per euro and $1.51 per British pound for the remainder of the quarter, which would result in average exchange rates that would be weaker by about 13% for the euro and about 4% for the British pound as compared to the prior year.
I also highlight that the euro and British pound as well as several other important currencies for our business, including the Brazilian Real the mother Russian ruble and the Australian dollar, have devalued compared to the U.S. dollar since reported earnings in August, and with most analysts last update to their forecasts.  Overall since that point in time, we estimate that foreign exchange rate fluctuations have negatively impacted our Q4 U.S. dollar forecasted results by about 2%.
As a result of exchange rate fluctuations, our gross bookings gross profit, operating expenses, adjusted EBITDA, and non-GAAP net income will mathematically translate into significantly fewer dollars than they would have at last year's exchange rates for Q4. 
Borrowing further deterioration in exchange rates, we believe that year-over-year currency comps will become less challenging after Q4. For Q4 guidance, we are forecasting total gross bookings to grow by 13% to 20% on a constant currency basis, and by 1% to 8% in U.S. dollars, with U.S. gross bookings down by 5% to 10% compared with prior year.  We expect international gross bookings to grow by 17% to 24% on a constant currency basis, and by 3% to 10% in U.S. dollars.
Our Q4 forecast assumes that constant currency ADRs for the consolidated group will be up by less than 2% compared to the prior year period. We expect Q4 revenue to grow year-over-year by approximately 1% to 8%. We expect gross profit to grow by 14% to 21% on a constant currency basis, and by 3% to 10% in U.S. dollars.
We expect that declines in our Name Your Own Price services will negatively impact revenue growth rates in Q4. We expect about 140 bps of deleverage in non-GAAP operating margins compared to prior year, expressed as non-GAAP operating income as a percentage of gross profit. The deleverage is mainly attributable to our assumptions for online ad efficiency and OpEx.
Our online advertising efficiency forecast, as usual, since deterioration from current levels and provides us with flexibility in a dynamic market to follow our consistent approach of advertising our brands and to reasonable ROIs. OpEx leverage has improved compared to earlier in the year, as we have lapped the OpenTable and BookingSuite acquisitions.
We are committed to controlling nonadvertising OpEx, and expect that these expenses to generally grow more slowly than our gross profit in the future, although there could be quarterly variations from time to time as we invest to be ready for growth. This cost discipline, together with industry-leading operating margins, allows us to lean in more aggressively when we see opportunities to advertise our brands to drive growth.
Our adjusted EBITDA is expected to range between $710 million and $760 million, which at the midpoint, is an increase of 3% versus prior year.  We estimate that the currency impact on EBITDA growth is similar to the impact that we are forecasting for gross profit. 
Our non-GAAP EPS forecast includes an estimated cash income tax rate of approximately 17%, comprised of international income taxes and alternative minimum tax and state income taxes in the U.S.  We are targeting non-GAAP fully diluted EPS of approximately $11.10 to $11.90 per share, which at the midpoint is an increase of 6% versus prior year. Our non-GAAP EPS guidance assumes a fully-diluted share count of 50.9 million shares based upon yesterday's closing stock price, and reflects the beneficial impact of the share repurchases we have made thus far this year.  We forecast GAAP EPS between $9.10 and $9.90 per share for Q4. The difference between our GAAP and non-GAAP results is driven by non-GAAP adjustments that are detailed in our earnings release.
Consistent with past practice, we have hedge contracts in place to substantially shield our fourth quarter EBITDA and net earnings from any further fluctuation in the euro and British pound versus the dollar, between now and the end of the quarter. The hedges do not offset the impact of translation on our gross bookings, revenue, gross profit or operating income. They also do not hedge us against fluctuations in other currencies, and do not hedge our earnings beyond the fourth quarter. Our forecast does not assume any significant change in macroeconomic conditions.
One housekeeping item. After reporting Q4, we will no longer report U.S. gross bookings as a separate statistical metric. We believe that the usefulness of this metric has diminished due to the relative size of our U.S. business to our consolidated results and because 2 of our 3 U.S. businesses do not have gross travel bookings. We will continue to report revenue and gross profit for our U.S. business, to give insight into its performance.
We will now take your questions.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Tom White with Macquarie.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Tom White with Macquarie.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Room nights, looks like there was a bit of a slowdown there, also in international gross bookings growth x FX. But the international gross profit growth x FX remains strong and steady, I think it was 29% versus last quarter. So could you maybe just talk a
componenttext: Room nights, looks like there was a bit of a slowdown there, also in international gross bookings growth x FX. But the international gross profit growth x FX remains strong and steady, I think it was 29% versus last quarter. So could you maybe just talk about the drivers of the delta there with the geographic mix to great improvements, just any impact from M&A? And then just on the U.S. business, I think you're largest competitor grew organic room nights, something like 25% in the U.S. last quarter -- impressive given that, that market is considered more mature. Just maybe, an update around your U.S. business? Is it mostly priceline.com, is it mostly booking.com, and kind of what's stopping you guys from getting your growth rates up to more competitive levels there?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, thanks, Tom. I'll let Dan take the first question. I'll take the second question.
componenttext: Yes. Well, thanks, Tom. I'll let Dan take the first question. I'll take the second question.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Tom, so on the first one, first of all, relative to the growth in Q3, we think our marketing teams that are great job of bringing traffic with a good balance between strong top line growth and really, strong bottom line growth, so we were happy with the m
componenttext: Tom, so on the first one, first of all, relative to the growth in Q3, we think our marketing teams that are great job of bringing traffic with a good balance between strong top line growth and really, strong bottom line growth, so we were happy with the margin performance and the top line performance in Q3. In terms of the difference between the growth rate and room nights and constant currency gross bookings growth versus our constant currency gross profit growth, there's a few things in there. First of all, there is a bit of an acquisition benefit, so we have about 1 percentage point of inorganic growth from the OpenTable acquisition, which benefits gross profit and has no impact on gross bookings. I mentioned for our U.S. business and this partly assess your last question, too -- We had a significant step down, 13% reduction in year-over-year airfares, which dramatically impacts gross bookings for the U.S. business but has no impact on gross profit. And then lastly, and probably, most significantly is just -- we had 2 very strong quarters of accelerating growth for room nights, and we're seeing the benefit of that now flow-through in Q3, together with just a strong performance relative to our forecast for bookings that came over the trend after we gave out guidance and actually checked out in Q3.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And just building on Dan's point, the U.S. growth numbers you see did not include Booking.com, and we feel very good about our Booking.com business in the U.S. There's 2 things I would comment. One is U.S. inbound, which obviously has been weaker bec
componenttext: Yes. And just building on Dan's point, the U.S. growth numbers you see did not include Booking.com, and we feel very good about our Booking.com business in the U.S. There's 2 things I would comment. One is U.S. inbound, which obviously has been weaker because of the strong dollar. And we did particularly well with the European and South American is coming into the U.S. but still, we put some pretty solid numbers on the board. And the other business -- the way I look at the businesses with U.S. as bookers which grew even faster than the U.S. as a destination, and we were serving U.S. bookers, not just for booking in the United States but also, overseas. So overall, we feel great about our U.S. business. But there's a lot more to do. It's one of the big markets where we are definitely under indexed. And we feel like we have a good set of cards to be able to compete -- continue to compete in the U.S. adn North America markets going forward.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Tom, just a follow-up to my answer -- you asked about take rates. Said in the prepared remarks, our take rates were stable. So that was not a driver of the gross profit growth in excess of gross bookings growth.
componenttext: And Tom, just a follow-up to my answer -- you asked about take rates. Said in the prepared remarks, our take rates were stable. So that was not a driver of the gross profit growth in excess of gross bookings growth.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Brian Fitzgerald with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question is from Brian Fitzgerald with Jefferies.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: I had a couple of questions around instant book. Can you talk a little bit more maybe, about the decision process to move forward there? You mentioned the requirement for prominent branding. How different are the mechanics there, versus what you do with K
componenttext: I had a couple of questions around instant book. Can you talk a little bit more maybe, about the decision process to move forward there? You mentioned the requirement for prominent branding. How different are the mechanics there, versus what you do with KAYAK? And then at the end of the day, do you kind of view it as -- it's just another ad format where you can proactively judge the ROI of the channel, and you can adjust exposure to that type of format accordingly? I mean, do you still own the hotel and the customer relationships. So a little bit about that, please.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, Brian. So we -- if you -- KAYAK was actually the original player to correct an instant book path, and frankly speaking, it's not very well branded path. And we before we bought KAYAK, we had also decided not to participate in that. We've part
componenttext: Yes, thanks, Brian. So we -- if you -- KAYAK was actually the original player to correct an instant book path, and frankly speaking, it's not very well branded path. And we before we bought KAYAK, we had also decided not to participate in that. We've participated in it and then it was a proliferation of these concepts in various META partners. Let's say, Tripadvisor probably the one taking it on most. So we've stayed out of it, mostly as we watched the performance KAYAK, but we want to make sure we had in any future instant book partnership, with first of all, great branding and secondly, the ability to market to the guests the work on our platform. And over the course of -- over 12 months, we finally came to an agreement where we think we can achieve that. We also believe we're going to get good ROIs half off of the Ctrip's platform. We think that branding is going to help us. And we also believe that we protected our content. We don't want our content being used to help other people book. We want our content to be used to help us book. I think working with TripAdvisor, we came to a nice -- good compromised agreement that allows us to achieve that. It also helps TripAdvisor in their strategic move to try to do more on mobile and other kind of small screen real estate. So overall, really positive. As I said, you guys will be able to see it very soon. We're beginning to test on small samples this week with TripAdvisor. And I'm now quite excited that this will be a nice new addition to places that we can get branded bookings from -- across our various marketing partners.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Eric Sheridan with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question is from Eric Sheridan with UBS.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: So maybe just following up on that. Wondering long-term -- would you think about these platforms for sort of book on trip or book on Google, how do you think about the ROI developing long-term on these platforms and the interplay between auction and commi
componenttext: So maybe just following up on that. Wondering long-term -- would you think about these platforms for sort of book on trip or book on Google, how do you think about the ROI developing long-term on these platforms and the interplay between auction and commission rates on those platforms? And then, maybe just 1 quick follow-up on health of consumer. Curious if there are comments you had half of the consumer, travel trends you saw coming out of the summer season, especially in Europe?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, okay. So let me take book of those questions. Yes, we are, on margin, ROI agnostic across various sources of demand. Of course, there are types of demand that work well for us, where we'll get really how the customer repeat, that we like the way that
componenttext: Yes, okay. So let me take book of those questions. Yes, we are, on margin, ROI agnostic across various sources of demand. Of course, there are types of demand that work well for us, where we'll get really how the customer repeat, that we like the way that the channels are working, that we might lean in a little bit more. And then other channels where we may be getting customers, but we don't like the nature of the customer -- they're not repeating in the right fashion, then we'll lean back from that. So right agnostic in that sense. I think the TripAssist's execution is one that we would like to use across other partners. We have been -- we will make some changes in KAYAK. We have been work very closely with Google, with Trivago -- other players. And I don't think it's going to enhance ROIs. I don't think it'll bleed away from ROIs. And we're going to have to watch as these things come together, and we really get used to the consumer behavior, and whether or not this is a channel we will lean into or lean back from.  But overall, we always try to earn money on every transaction regardless, and this will be a net positive from a cash flow standpoint for us, although not extremely material given kind of the size and scale of our business today. And then just some comments geographically. We saw a lot of strength in many areas of the market and we saw earlier in the year -- Japanese inbound, China outbound continues to be very strong. U.K. and U.S. outbound because both had relatively strong currencies, relative to where there they're traveling to. Europe we're seeing some pretty promising trends in southern Europe. Greece had a big issue as you know early in the summer, but Spain and Italy were both big positives for us in the summer. Maybe there's a bit of travel moving around, but most people in the Eurozone, state in Europe -- and many bespoke came to the Eurozone, so it was a very strong summer. And that respect. I'd say, challenges, you have these spot crises going on. We now have this 1 in Egypt. You saw in Tunisia and the Greek crisis. Russia, generally, inbound -- outbound is a challenge. There's a lot of travel going on in domestic Russia, but you guys know that whole story. Southeast Asia had the bombing, and then you had MERS in Korea, those were also negatives in the quarter. But overall, we run a very global mobile and diversified business. So I would say, this is certainly our best summer ever, if you look at just the volume of business we did. The profitability of the business. And we've now been able to our -- business is such that we can take advantage of both the positive and clean-up the negative. And going into Q4, we're feeling pretty good about the overall travel environment. I always remind people that travel is for -- is all of our headlines. People lose security when they see a negative headlines. And when the headlines are generally not negative, they're going to have to be positive, then people will travel, and we continue to see a very positive trends going into Q4 as well.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Naved Khan with Cantor Fitzgerald.
componenttext: Our next question is from Naved Khan with Cantor Fitzgerald.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015

componenttext: Darren, how do you balance of sort of the visibility you have on the TripAdvisor META auction, versus -- now your presentation with instant book, how do you sort of decide where do you want to play more? And then in terms of -- just the cost side of the integration. Is there any onetime costs that are baked into your 4Q guidance for the instant book?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. I didn't -- your first question, I didn't...
componenttext: Okay. I didn't -- your first question, I didn't...

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Balance for inbound [ph] instant book.
componenttext: Balance for inbound [ph] instant book.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Balance between matter and instant book. Well, first of all, I'll take the second question. There aren't really any costs. There was a lot of dev work that had to happen to make the instant book path work. We've been working with TripAdvisor very closely,
componenttext: Balance between matter and instant book. Well, first of all, I'll take the second question. There aren't really any costs. There was a lot of dev work that had to happen to make the instant book path work. We've been working with TripAdvisor very closely, and now already have established these and things like that. So that was not a big cost on our side. Yes, certainly, we -- when we look at all of our source to pray, demand, we're always looking for the right balance. We tend to prefer BlueLinx. I call them versus pads where somebody else tries to build the booking path, probably, because with think our booking path is the absolute best in industry. We're an agency model, so we use a credit card as a form of guarantee -- not a form of payment. These are all reasons why these instant book path, at times, have not been as strong of opportunities for us as blue links or META links. On the other hand, there is some benefits in terms of the branding and the marketing and also, the connectedness that we will be showing with TripAdvisor, because when they pick you to do their instant book, they're basically saying, "Hey, here's a great -- preferred partner to do business with." And that's positive -- China and us -- as well as on TripAdvisor. I think it's something that we're going to have to see how that works over time. But I'm kind of excited to see that because in a way, we never really in many of our other channels, we don't get that kind of endorsement. But in instant book path, that's one of the positives, given that it's a branded path that we're looking forward to. And you guys will be able to see again very soon what that looks like in the -- and you'll get a better sense of what I'm referring to.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: And quickly, I think you mentioned a new operating in tech stock which is launching soon. Can you just elaborate a little bit on that and what you see there?
componenttext: And quickly, I think you mentioned a new operating in tech stock which is launching soon. Can you just elaborate a little bit on that and what you see there?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. We -- when we went -- we've been -- Priceline has been an outstanding business for many, many years. But we found that the tech stock was in near as flexible and fungible as, for instance, the Text Types we had at Booking.com, or even rentalcars.com.
componenttext: Yes. We -- when we went -- we've been -- Priceline has been an outstanding business for many, many years. But we found that the tech stock was in near as flexible and fungible as, for instance, the Text Types we had at Booking.com, or even rentalcars.com. So now that we're getting into that, it'll be -- we've already had an experimentation framework, but it is much just a more flexible stack to allow for a much more rapid velocity and innovation. And we hope in Q1 that'll be fully in place. Paul is leading that business -- has decided to put focus there. Forever, we had sort of 2 stacks running in parallel, and now we'll be able to go under a single stack that'll also increased innovation speed, so people are creating code for 2 different stacks of software. It's not the funnest thing to go through, but we're seeing the light at the end of the tunnel, and we expect hopefully to get some good innovation velocity out of that and certainly, the team at priceline.com is very excited to get through this process.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Mark Mahaney with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question is from Mark Mahaney with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two questions, please. First is to do with his Murphy's. Darren, you mentioned earlier that you're not charging consumer fees. Do you -- and then there's 2 -- Expedia, HomeAway talked about doing that with the HomeAway assets -- and obviously, Airbnb is d
componenttext: Two questions, please. First is to do with his Murphy's. Darren, you mentioned earlier that you're not charging consumer fees. Do you -- and then there's 2 -- Expedia, HomeAway talked about doing that with the HomeAway assets -- and obviously, Airbnb is doing that. Is it something that your research indicates is important to consumers? Is it -- and is that why you're sticking with it, or do you think that it's something you could tag along at some point? And then could you also -- secondly, just talk about Facebook as a marketing channel and then any of your thoughts you had in that?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Mark. The -- basically, in vacation rentals, we're building a very different product than what Airbnb has or what HomeAway has. And our whole businesses based on the feature consumer. So it wasn't a strategic move, just a reflection of the w
componenttext: Okay. Thanks, Mark. The -- basically, in vacation rentals, we're building a very different product than what Airbnb has or what HomeAway has. And our whole businesses based on the feature consumer. So it wasn't a strategic move, just a reflection of the way that our business works. And we charge our accommodation partners between 12% and 15% commission, so that's where the take rate is. When you're in a classified ad business, it's more difficult to get that kind of take rate from the accommodation partner. So many players will try to also charge a fee or increase fees to consumers. We certainly believe that having a no free product drives conversion for us so we have a -- we obviously have the benefit of having a digital calendar and an instantly verifiable booking. Even the online bookings on HomeAway are on request, or on Airbnb are on request. So that's the whole process where the consumers both deciding and the property still deciding whether they want the product that they booked. So no, we feel really good about our positioning. It wasn't -- is more just reflective of the way our entire business works on Booking.com. But if you look at the way the competitive landscape is shaping up, we feel great that our product is -- both and the consumer lvoe, but is also -- has the least friction of any other products in the market.  And then our next question on Facebook as a marketing platform, we have been doing more and more business with Facebook. Most of it, though, is in the category or remessaging or retargeting. It's not really in the big sweet spot, which is intent-based based marketing. That's really what search gives you -- is that it is intent-based marketing. Somebody types in, "I want a hotel in New York." And then you're responding to that request. So -- but the folks at Facebook very much understand this -- they're working to try to win that kind of business. It's direct business. It's a big price for any marketing channel. And we're also trying to work with other large audience versus -- in Silicon Valley to try to get at that Holy Grail of intent-based marketing. It's really valuable to us as it is to any of them, and we're 1 of the world's best at it. And I feel like its other bit strange -- the advertiser going and working with the media partner to figure these things up, but there's a lot to begin by both. And I look forward to seeing where it goes. I've been really pleased, in particular, with Facebook's cooperation in this area and have engineers, working with engineers which is usually a good sign that they're going to figure out something.

componenttext: Hey, Ken. We could consider, at some point, giving some stats on the U.S. in terms of our total wholesale business. We haven't until now, but in the past, we've given some milestones like in size of our European business or our Latin America business. So I would've preclude the possibility of us doing that at some point. We've opted not to do that as an ongoing metric. We split our business now based upon where the brand is located and we've stopped that for the long time -- we'll stick with that for the future, but we will consider that at some point in the future.

We're pleased with the top line growth. We are pleased with the improvement in ROI is that we saw the quarter. And in that metric are also benefited by some of that flowthrough the bookings that we had made an prior quarters and advertising men, and recognize the gross profit as our customers traveled in Q3. So it was a good performance. I wouldn't split it by region for you.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, okay. And then if I can ask another, on BookingSuite. Can you just give us any sense for how big that might be right now in terms of the partnerships? And then how you're kind of going to market with that? Are you leveraging your existing sales force
componenttext: Yes, okay. And then if I can ask another, on BookingSuite. Can you just give us any sense for how big that might be right now in terms of the partnerships? And then how you're kind of going to market with that? Are you leveraging your existing sales force and kind of of what are the response rates like from hotels there?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Lloyed, yes, overall, our BookingSuite is growing very well for competitive reasons -- we don't want to talk about how many contracts or anything, but we have multiple -- more than when Buuteeq was an independent business. The way it's basically wor
componenttext: Okay. Lloyed, yes, overall, our BookingSuite is growing very well for competitive reasons -- we don't want to talk about how many contracts or anything, but we have multiple -- more than when Buuteeq was an independent business. The way it's basically working is our account managers. We'll introduced the concept of websites and other technical solutions to partners and then ask them "Would you like to hear more?" And then we have a secondary team that will then speak with a partner about the offerings that we have. We started out with websites, we've now bought a company called PriceMatch over in France, so we're developing business intelligence tools. The ultimate goal of BookingSuite is to have a whole suite of products that meets the needs of accommodation partners in the cloud, and that's what we're building toward. So a lot of innovation happening in the business, I am very happy with where it is. It's not a big contributor to EBITDA or anything at this point, but it's on a good pace and certainly, ahead of what -- where I thought it would've been at this point. It's really strategic for us. It's an area that -- getting into the Software business scenario, we can build close relationships with our partners and more to come.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Ron Josey with JMP Securities.
componenttext: Our next question is from Ron Josey with JMP Securities.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to switch topics, maybe ask about business travel. I think it's now 20% of bookings. Is it something that's ramped relatively recently for you all and have you placing emphasis on this before, and I'm just wondering -- the 20% number seems very h
componenttext: I wanted to switch topics, maybe ask about business travel. I think it's now 20% of bookings. Is it something that's ramped relatively recently for you all and have you placing emphasis on this before, and I'm just wondering -- the 20% number seems very high. And then I also wanted to ask about loyalty rates of these travelers, please. Meaning, do you see them coming back in higher amounts for peak usage?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks, Ron. Yes, what we've -- it's funny, we'll never before last Booking.com for business. We had never really specifically targeted the business traveler. But we had a pretty good sense that business will start to shop to the platform. We see th
componenttext: Well, thanks, Ron. Yes, what we've -- it's funny, we'll never before last Booking.com for business. We had never really specifically targeted the business traveler. But we had a pretty good sense that business will start to shop to the platform. We see them using their business e-mail address is the one indication we have. So starting about 2 years ago, we begin to say, "Okay, how do we address the business traveler better?" As you notice on our website, we don't have to set up for the tool, but if you say you're traveling on business, we'll highlight hotels that are great for business people. We'll show the review score, adjust from businesspeople. We'll show you amenities that businesspeople care about -- things like free WiFi, breakfast, fitness facility, things like that. That was the beginning of it. And then we start to see that people who marked their bookings as business booking, was going faster than even leisure bookers, so then we built a really lightweight tool that helped the systems book on behalf of business brokers, help them track budgets, things like that. And then we saw another pretty good boost to the business. So yes, 1 out of 5 today, there's various people who think that it should be -- I would say, 1 of the 2 sometime, in the long-term, because the business is basically half of accommodations around the world. There's different reports -- it might be 40%, it might be 60% but it's a wide variance. So we're going to continue to build in this space. But we've seen really positive traction. The benefits of business booking to us are their -- generally, they smooth out seasonality which is nice. I don't cancel as much -- generally higher ADR than leisure bookings. So there's a lot of positive benefits of business bookers. But as I remind people that every business person is a leisure traveler. Not every leisure traveler is a business person. But when you do both kinds of travel, and if you're able to do them on 1 platform, there are a lot of benefits to that. And we, of course, give the tool for free to give customer service for free, which is not the case will auto show imagine companies and support businesses today. So step-by-step, we're optimizing the product, and we're quite optimistic about it for the future.

componenttext: I had 2 questions. And then secondly, when you talked about adding hotels in China, is that in partnership with Ctrip, or you're adding at inventory independently from Ctrip? componenttext: Mike, I might won't quantify for you, specifically but I would say it's a significant impact for Agoda because it's by far, their largest market as a destination, so definitely noticeable, principally for our Agoda business.

componenttextpreview: Yes. And relative to the increase the properties in China, it's good you asked. Actually, the vast majority of them were built by Booking.com. They weren't acquired through the Ctrip partnership. We do have a, let's call it, a small handful of hotels that
componenttext: Yes. And relative to the increase the properties in China, it's good you asked. Actually, the vast majority of them were built by Booking.com. They weren't acquired through the Ctrip partnership. We do have a, let's call it, a small handful of hotels that we have as a future partnership, we're still optimizing. We had a lot of issues connecting systems, a lot of issues with the high bars that Booking.com has on content. And we want to make sure that the product in China is working absolutely in an outstanding fashion. And the Ctrip team has been responding to that. We haven't given up on it. But the numbers you're seeing have been largely self built by booking with a few handfuls. The other side of the commercial partnership with Ctrip is our product on their side, and that's gone very well and continues to grow. So I appreciate you asking. But we -- if we do unlock Ctrip, to provide an extra boost to our property count but right now, this is organic efforts going on at okay.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015

componenttext: Our next question is from Justin Post with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have a couple of questions. It looks like the booking upside you had this quarter versus prior quarters was a little bit less. Were there any changes and trends in the quarter that you'd like to call out versus, say, 2Q? And then the TripAdvisor partner
componenttext: I have a couple of questions. It looks like the booking upside you had this quarter versus prior quarters was a little bit less. Were there any changes and trends in the quarter that you'd like to call out versus, say, 2Q? And then the TripAdvisor partnership, after not being partners for a while, is very interesting. Any concerns you might have on kind of helping build the competitive platform over time, and just how are you thinking about that?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Hey, Justin, so I'll take the first one. No change, no -- nothing that I'd call out in terms of any kind of change in our approach. I think it was a really spectacular performance in the first couple of quarters for the business to accelerate. And i
componenttext: Okay. Hey, Justin, so I'll take the first one. No change, no -- nothing that I'd call out in terms of any kind of change in our approach. I think it was a really spectacular performance in the first couple of quarters for the business to accelerate. And if anything, maybe that's more of the outlier than seeing a bit of a deceleration in Q3 if you look at the business over kind of the balance of the 3 quarters, I think it's just very solid growth. And that's pretty much what we've seen over a number of years now as business has been very resilient, growing a very high rates. Every now and then, there'll be a stepdown, maybe a little bit bigger than what we're anticipating. And then the other point, there'll be a quarter where we'll accelerate. But overall, we're pleased with the performance year-to-date and in the third quarter, specifically.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. On the TripAdvisor, I think I largely answered it. It's obviously, it's a very tricky area and we would never want to do, is be a dumb pipe to somebody else's brand, and we would never want to give our content over to somebody to book other people's
componenttext: Yes. On the TripAdvisor, I think I largely answered it. It's obviously, it's a very tricky area and we would never want to do, is be a dumb pipe to somebody else's brand, and we would never want to give our content over to somebody to book other people's bookings. And you'll see that we've done neither of those. So I feel great about where we came out. And time will tell. Of course, every paid marketing partner we have, starting with Google, all the way down, has always ad spreads, and you have to make a really strong balance between the channels you're participating and how you're participating relative to the ROIs. And I think we do a really good job of that every single day. And I believe time will tell. I also, by the way, think it it's good for TripAdvisor, and that's kind of the nature of partnership is -- they've got something that they need to achieve, we've got something we need to achieve. And there was opportunity to come up with an answer, and that's what we did. So let's see. I mean, we will -- of the best thing situations is to find a good way to get in and began experimenting and optimizing and ultimately, we both win if we can find a way to get a lot more bookings.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe if I could ask a follow-up. If TripAdvisor goes well for you, could it be actually material for your overall bookings at all?
componenttext: Maybe if I could ask a follow-up. If TripAdvisor goes well for you, could it be actually material for your overall bookings at all?

componenttextpreview: We didn't build any assumption in, Justin. I think it's premature to make a call on that fashion. We'll see what the trade-off is between META and instant book and -- how much traction it gets, and then we'll report back to you after hold more information
componenttext: We didn't build any assumption in, Justin. I think it's premature to make a call on that fashion. We'll see what the trade-off is between META and instant book and -- how much traction it gets, and then we'll report back to you after hold more information.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. We have a very -- I guess it's were saying, with a very large business and we have a lot of varied channels -- and summer coming and going at all times, as Dan said, there's a whole cannibalization impact, we don't know, whether that's going to be a
componenttext: Yes. We have a very -- I guess it's were saying, with a very large business and we have a lot of varied channels -- and summer coming and going at all times, as Dan said, there's a whole cannibalization impact, we don't know, whether that's going to be a TripAdvisor as the media owner, how much do they expose of this product versus the other product. What's the balance that the customer wants to go? Do they want to go down the meta path, do they want to go down the assist path -- lots to learn. TripAdvisor is obviously a big player for us, but there's still a -- overall, a small percentage of our overall business, so it would have to be quite a significant incremental uptick to have a material impact on our results.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015

componenttext: Our next question is from Stephen Ju with Crédit Suisse.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Darren, my understanding is that ago to is a merchant base platform and now it seems like integrating Booking.com's agency inventory there. So is agency the direction you want to take with Agoda the future, or are you leaving the option open to the con
componenttext: So Darren, my understanding is that ago to is a merchant base platform and now it seems like integrating Booking.com's agency inventory there. So is agency the direction you want to take with Agoda the future, or are you leaving the option open to the consumer?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Stephen. I would say more leaving the option. If you look at priceline.com, it's a real mix of merchant and agency, and there are ways to merchandise the product. We've always had Booking.com on Agoda, although it's pretty varied. And only recentl
componenttext: Thanks, Stephen. I would say more leaving the option. If you look at priceline.com, it's a real mix of merchant and agency, and there are ways to merchandise the product. We've always had Booking.com on Agoda, although it's pretty varied. And only recently that we really up our -- Booking.com upped presence on Agoda, and now there's a really nice mix. So the customer often comes down to "Do I pay now or do I pay later?" how cancellable is the products, things like that. Which can be messaged in the path. They don't necessarily see it as an agency versus a merchant product. It's just a different way to experience their accommodation from payment standpoint.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015

componenttext: Our next question is from Heath Terry with Goldman Sachs.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015

componenttext: I wanted to dig a little bit deeper into the math behind the advertising deleverage that you talked to and just get a bit of an update on the mix there in terms of what you're seeing that's driving that, whether it's deleveraging within specific channels sort of same-store sales basis, or it's just a mixed shift to less efficient channels as you sort of maxed out the traffic that you can get through more efficient channels like Google? And then Dan, I do want to come back on this U.S. bookings question. Just get a sense -- I know you talk about some incremental disclosures. But this which I and nonetheless, analyze the business going forward and obviously, the trends in the U.S. the trends are, as you guys put it up in your comments, the trends in individual geographic regions, start to matter a lot more. Is there a sense or any sort of guidance you want to give us in terms of the best way to look at that geographic exposure in the business since we're not getting going to be having the kind of disclosure that you've given in the past?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015

componenttext: Sure. So I'll take both of those. On ad deleverage, what are you talking about specifically? In the guidance or in the Q3?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: More in the guidance but just sort of general trends, either way. But the comments that you made earlier in the call during the prepared remarks on the ad deleverage implied for Q4, mainly just looking to get a better sense of whether that's specific chan
componenttext: More in the guidance but just sort of general trends, either way. But the comments that you made earlier in the call during the prepared remarks on the ad deleverage implied for Q4, mainly just looking to get a better sense of whether that's specific channels becoming less efficient over time or mixed shift as you're having to explore other channels that are less efficient because the capacity within your more mature, more efficient channels?

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. No, so it's no significant assumed change in mix or channels. It's more -- just looking at what we've delivered, thus far to date in the quarter in terms of ad ROIs, and then building a level of conservatism on top of that for the go forward, real
componenttext: Got it. No, so it's no significant assumed change in mix or channels. It's more -- just looking at what we've delivered, thus far to date in the quarter in terms of ad ROIs, and then building a level of conservatism on top of that for the go forward, really just to give our marketing team some flexibility, that if they do see channels that they think are attractive and they want to lean in a little bit, or the marketplace becomes more competitive, that we've got the ability to hold position and maybe, accept somewhat lower ROI. So it's really just to give us some flexibility to compete in a very dynamic marketplace, and look for opportunities to again, try and strike a good balance between top line and bottom line growth without feeling that they're handcuffed -- having to deliver a specific ROI.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: The other thing, just might just talk about Q4 a little bit and how acceleration and growth bookings can actually cost you in Q4, for a check out in Q1.
componenttext: The other thing, just might just talk about Q4 a little bit and how acceleration and growth bookings can actually cost you in Q4, for a check out in Q1.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Q3, we got the benefit of the acceleration that happen in the first couple of quarters and checked out in Q3. A little bit of a deceleration and gross bookings growth is generally helpful to that ad efficiency metric. And that top line forecast th
componenttext: Yes. So Q3, we got the benefit of the acceleration that happen in the first couple of quarters and checked out in Q3. A little bit of a deceleration and gross bookings growth is generally helpful to that ad efficiency metric. And that top line forecast that we have for Q4 is relatively stronger, I would say. So when you don't have the kind of deceleration in top line growth, that puts a little bit more pressure on the ad efficiency metric. In terms of the U.S. gross bookings, I'd say that the best way to look at our U.S. business and understand the trends will be the revenue and gross profit numbers that will continue to report. So revenue for OpenTable and KAYAK are reported in advertising and other. And then we'll give you the total U.S. revenue, which we'll kind of give you a proxy on priceline.com so you'll get a sense for our U.S. travel business.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our last question is from Kevin Kopelman with Cowen and company.
componenttext: Our last question is from Kevin Kopelman with Cowen and company.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is just the questionnaire vacation rental business. Can you give us an update there? Are you seeing any increasing competitiveness from Airbnb, and can you talk about your strategy for the U.S. in that business because it seems like you only have a f
componenttext: This is just the questionnaire vacation rental business. Can you give us an update there? Are you seeing any increasing competitiveness from Airbnb, and can you talk about your strategy for the U.S. in that business because it seems like you only have a few listings here today.

headline: The Priceline Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Kevin. Well, we -- first of all, it's always worth reminding people, this is a very large market, so you don't -- the competition you don't necessarily see on a day-to-day basis. And most of this market is booked in quite an inefficient way.
componenttext:
Yes. Thanks, Kevin. Well, we -- first of all, it's always worth reminding people, this is a very large market, so you don't -- the competition you don't necessarily see on a day-to-day basis. And most of this market is booked in quite an inefficient way. But when we look at what we call vacation rentals which is our self-catered product, we have an inventory of 1.8 million bookable rooms, that's in the ballpark of what HomeAway and Airbnb have. We may be booking different kinds of of properties, HomeAway's actually quite focused on vacation homes. We're quite heavy in city apartments and things like that. We are also at the end is very heavily in Europe. HomeAway index's -- and Airbnb, quite heavily in the United States. But we feel pretty good about the scale of our business, it's growth. The nature of our booker may be different. They're maybe somebody who's looking for any form of accommodation versus a vacation home, specifically. And this is a really critical market for us in the future. When you think about where we've come from, we came from the hotel space. We've now built a massive amount of inventory in multiroom unique accommodations that one would've technically call hotel, and now we're adding vacation homes. So that's the way we've approached the market. We feel good about our growth. It's quite fast and comfortable. And we're a profitable company, which is quite a difference as well. So we continue to build it out. I'd like the cars that we have, and I'm excited to look forward to where this all ends up. I think in the United States, for sure, there's forward to be done. And we now -- if you look at our total property count, we're right in there with Expedia, if not a little bit more. You can see these on the website. And we're going to continue to build out our unique accommodations portfolio in the United States and places that Americans like to go, that's really high priority for us and a big focus in the coming quarters.
Yes, thanks. Well, I guess that last question. Thank you all very much. It's been the biggest quarter in the history of The Priceline Group. But we continue to be very optimistic about the future and again, I want to thank all of our employees for a fantastic summer and looking forward to great 2016.
